# Capital Budget Template

## Purpose

This template is used to plan for significant long-term investments (Capital Expenditures or CapEx), such as equipment, property, or major software upgrades. It separates these large, one-time costs from the operating budget.

## Instructions

1.  **Identify Needs**: List required assets or improvements.
2.  **Estimate Costs**: Obtain quotes or estimates.
3.  **Justification**: Explain the ROI or necessity of the purchase.
4.  **Timing**: Schedule when the cash outlay will occur.

## Template

```markdown
# CAPITAL EXPENDITURE (CAPEX) BUDGET

**Entity**: [ENTITY NAME]
**Year**: [YEAR]

| Item Description | Justification/ROI | Estimated Cost | Purchase Date | Priority (H/M/L) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| [ITEM 1] | [REASON] | $[AMOUNT] | [DATE] | [PRIORITY] |
| [ITEM 2] | [REASON] | $[AMOUNT] | [DATE] | [PRIORITY] |
| [ITEM 3] | [REASON] | $[AMOUNT] | [DATE] | [PRIORITY] |

## TOTAL CAPEX BUDGET: $[AMOUNT]

## FUNDING SOURCE

- [ ] Operating Cash Flow: $[AMOUNT]
- [ ] Financing/Loans: $[AMOUNT]
- [ ] Capital Contribution: $[AMOUNT]

---

**Approved By**: [NAME]
**Date**: [DATE]
```

# Real Estate Option Contract Template

## Purpose

This template creates an option to purchase real estate, giving the option holder the right (but not obligation) to buy the property at a specified price within a set time period. This is useful for controlling property without immediate purchase.

**IMPORTANT**: Option contracts must comply with state real estate laws. Review with qualified counsel.

## Instructions

1. **Set Option Price**: Amount paid for the option (option fee)
2. **Set Exercise Price**: Price to purchase if option is exercised
3. **Set Term**: Time period to exercise option
4. **Define Terms**: Purchase terms if option is exercised
5. **Review with Attorney**: Must be reviewed by qualified counsel

## Template

```markdown
# REAL ESTATE OPTION CONTRACT

**Date**: [DATE]
**Option Number**: [NUMBER]

## PARTIES

**Optionor (Seller)**: [SELLER NAME/ENTITY]
Address: [ADDRESS]
Phone: [PHONE]
Email: [EMAIL]

**Optionee (Buyer)**: [BUYER NAME/ENTITY]
Address: [ADDRESS]
Phone: [PHONE]
Email: [EMAIL]

---

## PROPERTY DESCRIPTION

**Property Address**: [STREET ADDRESS], [CITY], [STATE] [ZIP]

**Legal Description**: [LEGAL DESCRIPTION FROM DEED]

**Parcel Number**: [PARCEL/TAX ID NUMBER]

---

## OPTION TERMS

### 1. Grant of Option

Optionor hereby grants to Optionee the exclusive right and option to purchase the Property on the terms set forth herein.

### 2. Option Price

Optionee has paid Optionor an option fee of **$[AMOUNT]** (the "Option Price") for the right to purchase the Property. This Option Price is:
- [ ] Non-refundable
- [ ] Credited toward purchase price if option is exercised
- [ ] [OTHER TERMS]

### 3. Exercise Price

If Optionee exercises this option, the purchase price shall be **$[AMOUNT]** (the "Exercise Price").

### 4. Option Term

This option may be exercised at any time on or before [DATE] (the "Expiration Date"). If not exercised by the Expiration Date, this option shall expire and be of no further effect.

### 5. Method of Exercise

Optionee may exercise this option by:
- Delivering written notice to Optionor at the address above
- Paying the Exercise Price (or portion as specified)
- [OTHER EXERCISE REQUIREMENTS]

---

## PURCHASE TERMS (IF OPTION EXERCISED)

### 6. Purchase Agreement

If option is exercised, the parties shall enter into a purchase agreement incorporating the following terms:

**Purchase Price**: $[AMOUNT] (Exercise Price)

**Earnest Money**: $[AMOUNT] (in addition to Option Price)

**Closing Date**: Within [NUMBER] days of exercise notice

**Financing**: [CONTINGENT/NOT CONTINGENT] upon financing

**Contingencies**: [LIST CONTINGENCIES - inspection, appraisal, etc.]

### 7. Title

Optionor shall provide marketable title free of liens and encumbrances except:
- [LIST PERMITTED EXCEPTIONS]

---

## OPTIONOR OBLIGATIONS

### 8. Property Maintenance

During the option term, Optionor shall:
- Maintain Property in current condition
- Not encumber Property with additional liens
- Allow Optionee reasonable access for inspections
- [OTHER OBLIGATIONS]

### 9. No Sale to Third Parties

Optionor shall not sell, lease, or encumber the Property to any third party during the option term without Optionee's written consent.

---

## OPTIONEE OBLIGATIONS

### 10. Option Price Payment

Optionee has paid the Option Price as set forth in Section 2.

### 11. Exercise Notice

If Optionee wishes to exercise, Optionee must provide written notice and payment as specified in Section 5.

---

## DEFAULT AND REMEDIES

### 12. Optionee Default

If Optionee fails to exercise by Expiration Date:
- Option expires
- Option Price is forfeited (if non-refundable)
- Optionor has no further obligations

### 13. Optionor Default

If Optionor breaches this Agreement:
- Optionee may seek specific performance
- Optionee may recover damages
- Option Price shall be refunded

---

## GENERAL PROVISIONS

### 14. Assignment

This option [MAY/MAY NOT] be assigned by Optionee to a third party.

### 15. Entire Agreement

This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the parties.

### 16. Governing Law

This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of [STATE].

---

## SIGNATURES

**OPTIONOR (SELLER)**:

_____________________________
[SELLER NAME/REPRESENTATIVE]
Date: _______________

**OPTIONEE (BUYER)**:

_____________________________
[BUYER NAME/REPRESENTATIVE]
Date: _______________

---

*This template is version 1.0 and was created for the Legacy Codex. All legal templates must be reviewed by qualified counsel before use.*
```

## Example

[Example filled version would show actual property details, option price, and exercise price]

## Notes

- **Option vs. Purchase**: An option gives the right to buy but not the obligation. The buyer can walk away and lose only the option fee.

- **Option Price**: Typically 1-5% of purchase price, but negotiable.

- **Exercise Price**: Can be fixed or based on appraisal at time of exercise.

- **Assignment**: Consider whether option should be assignable to third parties.

- **Tax Implications**: Option fees may have tax consequences. Consult tax advisor.

# Facebook/Meta Ads Copy Template

## Purpose

This template provides frameworks for writing effective Facebook and Instagram ad copy that stops the scroll and drives action.

## Instructions

1. **Know Your Audience**: Write in their language
2. **Lead with Hook**: First 3 words must grab attention
3. **Tell a Story**: Use narrative to engage
4. **Visual First**: Copy supports the image/video
5. **Clear CTA**: Make the next step obvious

## Template Structure

### Facebook Feed Ad

**Primary Text** (125 characters for best engagement):
> [HOOK - First 3 words critical]
> 
> [STORY OR BENEFIT]
> 
> [CALL TO ACTION]

**Headline** (40 characters):
> [BENEFIT OR OFFER]

**Description** (30 characters):
> [SUPPORTING DETAIL]

**CTA Button**: [Learn More / Shop Now / Sign Up / etc.]

---

## Ad Copy Variations

### Variation 1: Story-Driven

**Primary Text**:
> "I used to struggle with [PROBLEM]...
> 
> Then I discovered [SOLUTION].
> 
> Now I [BENEFIT].
> 
> Want the same results? [CTA]"

---

### Variation 2: Question Hook

**Primary Text**:
> "Are you tired of [PAIN POINT]?
> 
> You're not alone. Most [TARGET AUDIENCE] face this challenge.
> 
> Here's the solution: [BENEFIT]
> 
> [CTA] to learn more."

---

### Variation 3: Social Proof

**Primary Text**:
> "Join 10,000+ [TARGET AUDIENCE] who have [ACHIEVED RESULT]
> 
> [CLIENT NAME] said: '[TESTIMONIAL]'
> 
> Ready to get started? [CTA]"

---

### Variation 4: Offer-Driven

**Primary Text**:
> "Special Offer: [DISCOUNT]% Off
> 
> [PRODUCT/SERVICE] for just $[PRICE] (Regularly $[PRICE])
> 
> Limited time only. [CTA] to claim your discount."

---

## Instagram Ad Copy

**Caption** (Similar to Facebook, but shorter):
> [HOOK]
> 
> [BENEFIT]
> 
> [CTA]
> 
> [HASHTAGS]

**Note**: Instagram users prefer shorter, punchier copy.

---

## Best Practices

- **Hook**: First 3 words determine if they keep reading
- **Emojis**: Use sparingly (1-2 per post max)
- **Length**: Shorter often performs better (under 125 chars)
- **Questions**: Questions in first line increase engagement
- **Urgency**: "Limited time," "Only X left" create urgency

---

**Version**: 1.0  
**Last Updated**: [DATE]  
**Next Review**: [DATE + 3 MONTHS]

---

# LinkedIn Ads Copy Template

## Purpose

This template provides frameworks for writing effective LinkedIn ad copy for B2B marketing. LinkedIn ads work best with professional, value-driven messaging.

## Instructions

1. **Target Audience**: Write for professional decision-makers
2. **Professional Tone**: Maintain business-appropriate language
3. **Value-Focused**: Emphasize ROI and business outcomes
4. **Clear CTA**: Professional but direct call-to-action
5. **Test Variations**: Create multiple versions for optimization

## Template Structure

### LinkedIn Sponsored Content

**Headline** (150 characters):
> [BENEFIT OR VALUE PROPOSITION FOR TARGET AUDIENCE]

**Description** (600 characters):
> [EXPAND ON HEADLINE]
> 
> [PROOF POINT OR CASE STUDY]
> 
> [CLEAR CTA]

**CTA Button**: [Learn More / Download / Register / Get Started]

---

## Ad Copy Variations

### Variation 1: Problem-Solution (B2B)

**Headline**: "Are [TARGET AUDIENCE] Struggling with [PROBLEM]?"

**Description**:
> "Many [TARGET AUDIENCE] face [PROBLEM], costing them [QUANTIFIABLE LOSS] annually.
> 
> Our [SOLUTION] helps [TARGET AUDIENCE] [ACHIEVE RESULT], saving an average of $[AMOUNT] per year.
> 
> [CLIENT NAME], a [INDUSTRY] company, achieved [SPECIFIC RESULT] using our solution.
> 
> Download our free guide: '[RESOURCE NAME]' to learn how."

**CTA**: "Download Free Guide"

---

### Variation 2: Thought Leadership

**Headline**: "New Research: [INSIGHT OR STATISTIC]"

**Description**:
> "Our latest study of [NUMBER] [TARGET AUDIENCE] reveals [KEY FINDING].
> 
> Key insights:
> • [INSIGHT 1]
> • [INSIGHT 2]
> • [INSIGHT 3]
> 
> Download the full report to see how this impacts your business."

**CTA**: "Download Report"

---

### Variation 3: Case Study

**Headline**: "How [CLIENT NAME] Achieved [RESULT]"

**Description**:
> "[CLIENT NAME], a [INDUSTRY] company, was struggling with [PROBLEM].
> 
> After implementing our [SOLUTION], they achieved:
> • [RESULT 1]
> • [RESULT 2]
> • [RESULT 3]
> 
> Read the full case study to see how we can help your business."

**CTA**: "Read Case Study"

---

### Variation 4: Webinar/Event

**Headline**: "Join Us: [EVENT NAME] - [DATE]"

**Description**:
> "Learn how [TARGET AUDIENCE] are [ACHIEVING RESULT] in this free webinar.
> 
> You'll discover:
> • [LEARNING POINT 1]
> • [LEARNING POINT 2]
> • [LEARNING POINT 3]
> 
> Featuring [SPEAKER NAME], [TITLE]. Limited seats available."

**CTA**: "Register Now"

---

## LinkedIn Message Ads

**Subject Line** (60 characters):
> [HOOK OR BENEFIT]

**Message** (300 characters):
> Hi [FIRST NAME],
> 
> [PERSONALIZED OPENING]
> 
> [VALUE PROPOSITION]
> 
> [CTA]
> 
> Best,
> [YOUR NAME]

---

## Best Practices

### Targeting
- **Job Title**: Target specific roles (CEO, CFO, Marketing Director)
- **Company Size**: Match to your ideal client size
- **Industry**: Focus on relevant industries
- **Seniority**: Target decision-makers

### Messaging
- **Professional**: Maintain business tone
- **Data-Driven**: Use statistics and proof points
- **ROI-Focused**: Emphasize business outcomes
- **Respectful**: Don't be overly salesy

### CTAs
- **Clear**: "Download," "Register," "Learn More"
- **Value-Driven**: "Get Free Guide," "See Case Study"
- **Action-Oriented**: Use action verbs

# Monthly Cash Flow Statement Template

## Purpose

This template provides a comprehensive monthly Cash Flow Statement for tracking cash inflows and outflows. Use this template to monitor cash position, identify cash flow trends, and plan for cash needs.

## Instructions

1. **Select Period**: Enter the month and year for the statement
2. **Starting Cash**: Enter beginning cash balance
3. **Operating Activities**: Record cash from operations
4. **Investing Activities**: Record cash from investing activities
5. **Financing Activities**: Record cash from financing activities
6. **Calculate Ending Cash**: Sum all activities to get ending cash balance
7. **Reconcile**: Reconcile to bank statements
8. **Analyze**: Review cash flow trends and variances

## Template

```markdown
# STATEMENT OF CASH FLOWS

**Entity Name**: [ENTITY NAME]  
**Statement Period**: [MONTH], [YEAR]  
**Prepared By**: [NAME]  
**Date Prepared**: [DATE]  
**Accounting Method**: [CASH/ACCRUAL]

---

## CASH FLOWS FROM OPERATING ACTIVITIES

### Cash Receipts

| Source | Amount |
|--------|--------|
| Cash received from customers | $[AMOUNT] |
| Interest received | $[AMOUNT] |
| Dividends received | $[AMOUNT] |
| Other operating receipts | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Total Cash Receipts** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

### Cash Payments

| Payment Type | Amount |
|--------------|--------|
| Payments to suppliers | $[AMOUNT] |
| Payments to employees | $[AMOUNT] |
| Interest paid | $[AMOUNT] |
| Income taxes paid | $[AMOUNT] |
| Other operating payments | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Total Cash Payments** | **($[AMOUNT])** |

### **Net Cash from Operating Activities** | **$[AMOUNT]**

---

## CASH FLOWS FROM INVESTING ACTIVITIES

| Activity | Amount |
|----------|--------|
| Purchase of property, plant, and equipment | ($[AMOUNT]) |
| Purchase of investments | ($[AMOUNT]) |
| Proceeds from sale of assets | $[AMOUNT] |
| Proceeds from sale of investments | $[AMOUNT] |
| Loans made to others | ($[AMOUNT]) |
| Collection of loans | $[AMOUNT] |
| Other investing activities | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Net Cash from Investing Activities** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

---

## CASH FLOWS FROM FINANCING ACTIVITIES

| Activity | Amount |
|----------|--------|
| Proceeds from borrowings | $[AMOUNT] |
| Repayment of borrowings | ($[AMOUNT]) |
| Proceeds from equity contributions | $[AMOUNT] |
| Distributions to owners | ($[AMOUNT]) |
| Payment of dividends | ($[AMOUNT]) |
| Other financing activities | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Net Cash from Financing Activities** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

---

## NET CHANGE IN CASH

**Net Cash from Operating Activities**: $[AMOUNT]  
**Net Cash from Investing Activities**: $[AMOUNT]  
**Net Cash from Financing Activities**: $[AMOUNT]  
**Net Change in Cash**: $[AMOUNT]

---

## CASH BALANCE

**Cash at Beginning of Period**: $[AMOUNT]  
**Net Change in Cash**: $[AMOUNT]  
**Cash at End of Period**: $[AMOUNT]

---

## RECONCILIATION TO BANK STATEMENTS

| Account | Beginning Balance | Ending Balance | Change |
|---------|------------------|----------------|--------|
| Operating Account | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Savings Account | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Petty Cash | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Total Cash** | **$[AMOUNT]** | **$[AMOUNT]** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

**Reconciliation**: Cash at End of Period = Total Cash from Bank Statements ✓

---

## RECONCILIATION OF NET INCOME TO NET CASH FROM OPERATING ACTIVITIES

**Net Income** (from P&L): $[AMOUNT]

### Adjustments for Non-Cash Items

| Adjustment | Amount |
|-----------|--------|

| Decrease in accounts payable | ($[AMOUNT]) |

## CASH FLOW ANALYSIS

**Operating Cash Flow Ratio** = Net Cash from Operating Activities / Current Liabilities
```

# Google Ads Copy Template

## Purpose

This template provides frameworks for writing effective Google Search and Display ad copy that drives clicks and conversions.

## Instructions

1. **Keyword Research**: Base copy on target keywords
2. **Match Intent**: Align copy with search intent
3. **Highlight Benefits**: Focus on what user gets, not features
4. **Include CTA**: Clear call-to-action in every ad
5. **Test Variations**: Create multiple versions for A/B testing

## Template Structure

### Google Search Ad (Standard)

**Headline 1** (30 characters):
> [BENEFIT OR KEYWORD]

**Headline 2** (30 characters):
> [DIFFERENT BENEFIT OR VALUE PROPOSITION]

**Headline 3** (30 characters):
> [CTA OR ADDITIONAL BENEFIT]

**Description 1** (90 characters):
> [EXPAND ON BENEFIT] [SUPPORTING DETAIL] [CTA]

**Description 2** (90 characters):
> [ADDITIONAL VALUE] [PROOF POINT] [URGENCY OR OFFER]

**Final URL**: [LANDING PAGE URL]

**Display Path** (optional):
- Path 1: [KEYWORD]
- Path 2: [BENEFIT]

---

## Ad Copy Variations

### Variation 1: Problem-Solution

**Headline 1**: "Tired of [PROBLEM]?"
**Headline 2**: "We Solve [PROBLEM] Fast"
**Headline 3**: "Get Results in [TIME]"

**Description 1**: "Stop struggling with [PROBLEM]. Our proven solution delivers [BENEFIT] in [TIME]. See how we helped [CLIENT TYPE]."

**Description 2**: "Join 10,000+ satisfied clients. Free consultation. No obligation. Get started today!"

---

### Variation 2: Benefit-Driven

**Headline 1**: "[BENEFIT] in [TIME]"
**Headline 2**: "Proven [SOLUTION]"
**Headline 3**: "Free [OFFER] - Limited Time"

**Description 1**: "Get [BENEFIT] without the hassle. Our [SOLUTION] has helped [NUMBER] clients achieve [RESULT]."

**Description 2**: "Risk-free trial. Money-back guarantee. See results in [TIME]. Start your free consultation now!"

---

### Variation 3: Offer-Driven

**Headline 1**: "[DISCOUNT]% Off [SERVICE]"
**Headline 2**: "Limited Time Offer"
**Headline 3**: "Claim Your Discount Today"

**Description 1**: "Special offer: [DISCOUNT]% off [SERVICE] for new clients. Regularly $[PRICE], now just $[PRICE]."

**Description 2**: "Offer expires [DATE]. Don't miss out. Book your free consultation and save [AMOUNT] today!"

---

### Variation 4: Social Proof

**Headline 1**: "Trusted by [NUMBER]+ Clients"
**Headline 2**: "[RATING] Star Rated [SERVICE]"
**Headline 3**: "See What Clients Say"

**Description 1**: "[CLIENT NAME] said: '[TESTIMONIAL]'. Join thousands of satisfied clients who chose [COMPANY]."

**Description 2**: "5-star reviews. Proven results. Free consultation. See why clients love us. Get started today!"

---

## Google Display Ad Copy

**Headline** (30 characters):
> [BENEFIT OR OFFER]

**Description** (90 characters):
> [VALUE PROPOSITION] [PROOF POINT] [CTA]

**Business Name**: [COMPANY NAME]

**CTA Button**: [Learn More / Get Started / Shop Now]

---

## Best Practices

### Headlines
- **Use Keywords**: Include target keywords naturally
- **Focus on Benefits**: What user gets, not what you do
- **Create Urgency**: Limited time, limited availability
- **Test Numbers**: "Save 50%" vs "Save $500"

### Descriptions
- **Expand on Headlines**: Provide more detail
- **Include Proof**: Numbers, testimonials, guarantees
- **Clear CTA**: Tell user exactly what to do
- **Use Extensions**: Utilize ad extensions for more space

### Extensions
- **Sitelink Extensions**: Link to key pages
- **Callout Extensions**: Additional benefits
- **Structured Snippets**: Features or services
- **Call Extension**: Phone number for mobile

---

## A/B Testing Framework

Test one element at a time:

**Test 1: Headlines**
- Version A: Benefit-focused
- Version B: Problem-focused

**Test 2: CTAs**
- Version A: "Get Started"
- Version B: "Free Consultation"

**Test 3: Offers**
- Version A: Percentage discount
- Version B: Dollar amount discount

# Cash Flow Forecast Template

## Purpose

This template helps businesses project future cash positions by estimating cash inflows and outflows over a specific period (usually 12 months). It is critical for avoiding liquidity crises and planning for capital expenditures.

## Instructions

1.  **Starting Balance**: Enter the actual cash balance at the start of Month 1.
2.  **Estimate Inflows**: Project sales receipts (consider payment delays/AR).
3.  **Estimate Outflows**: Project fixed costs (rent, payroll) and variable costs.
4.  **Calculate Net**: Inflows minus Outflows = Net Cash Flow.
5.  **Ending Balance**: Starting Balance + Net Cash Flow = Ending Balance.

- **Frequency**: Don't over-communicate - weekly or bi-weekly is usually sufficient

- **Visuals**: Consider including screenshots, charts, or progress indicators

# Cold Outreach Email Template

2.  **Personalize**: Use the [HOOK] to show you've done your homework.

# Consulting Agreement Template

## Purpose

This template is designed for consulting engagements where the provider offers expert advice, strategy, or specialized knowledge. It differs from a general services agreement by focusing on advisory roles and intellectual capital.

**IMPORTANT**: Review with legal counsel.

## Instructions

1.  **Define Scope**: Clearly articulate the consulting objectives and deliverables.
2.  **IP Rights**: Pay close attention to IP ownership of strategies and models developed.
3.  **Non-Compete**: Consider if a non-compete clause is appropriate (check state laws).

## Template

```markdown
# CONSULTING AGREEMENT

**Date**: [DATE]

**Consultant**: [CONSULTANT NAME] ("Consultant")
**Client**: [CLIENT NAME] ("Client")

## 1. ENGAGEMENT

Client hereby engages Consultant to provide the consulting services described in **Exhibit A** ("Services").

## 2. PERFORMANCE

Consultant shall perform the Services to the best of their ability, in a professional manner consistent with industry standards.

## 3. COMPENSATION

Client shall pay Consultant as follows:
- Rate: $[AMOUNT] per [HOUR/DAY/PROJECT]
- Retainer: $[AMOUNT] (if applicable)
- Payment Schedule: [DETAILS]

## 4. INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR STATUS

Consultant is an independent contractor and not an employee of Client. Consultant is responsible for all taxes and benefits.

## 5. CONFIDENTIALITY

Consultant acknowledges that they may have access to Client's confidential information. Consultant agrees not to disclose or use such information except for the benefit of Client.

## 6. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY

Any reports, strategies, or specific work product created solely for Client shall be the property of Client. Consultant retains ownership of their pre-existing methodologies, frameworks, and tools.

## 7. NON-SOLICITATION

During the term of this Agreement and for [NUMBER] months thereafter, Consultant shall not solicit Client's employees or customers.

## 8. TERMINATION

Either party may terminate this Agreement with [NUMBER] days' written notice. Client shall pay for all Services performed up to the date of termination.

## 9. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY

Consultant's liability shall be limited to the amount of fees paid by Client under this Agreement.

## 10. GOVERNING LAW

This Agreement is governed by the laws of [STATE].

---

**Signatures**:

Consultant: __________________________ Date: __________

Client: ______________________________ Date: __________

---

## EXHIBIT A: SERVICES

[Detailed description of consulting services]
```

# Employment Agreement Template

## Purpose

This agreement is for hiring W-2 employees. It outlines salary, benefits, duties, and "at-will" status.

**IMPORTANT**: Employment laws vary significantly by state. This is a general template and must be reviewed by local counsel.

## Instructions

1.  **Position**: Define the role and reporting structure.
2.  **Compensation**: State salary and pay frequency.
3.  **At-Will**: Confirm "at-will" employment (can be terminated at any time).
4.  **Restrictive Covenants**: Non-compete/Non-solicit clauses (check state enforceability).

## Template

```markdown
# EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT

**Date**: [DATE]

**Employer**: [COMPANY NAME]
**Employee**: [EMPLOYEE NAME]

## 1. POSITION AND DUTIES

Employer hires Employee for the position of [JOB TITLE]. Employee agrees to perform the duties associated with this position and report to [MANAGER TITLE]. Employee shall devote their full business time and attention to the Employer.

## 2. COMPENSATION

2.1 **Salary**. Employee shall receive a base salary of $[AMOUNT] per year, payable in accordance with Employer's standard payroll schedule.
2.2 **Benefits**. Employee shall be eligible to participate in standard benefit plans offered by Employer (e.g., health insurance, 401k), subject to plan terms.
2.3 **Bonus**. Employee [IS/IS NOT] eligible for discretionary bonuses based on performance.

## 3. AT-WILL EMPLOYMENT

Employee's employment is "at-will." This means that either Employee or Employer may terminate the employment relationship at any time, with or without cause, and with or without notice.

## 4. CONFIDENTIALITY AND IP

4.1 **Confidentiality**. Employee agrees not to disclose Employer's confidential information or trade secrets during or after employment.
4.2 **Intellectual Property**. All work created by Employee during employment belongs to Employer.

## 5. RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS

5.1 **Non-Solicitation**. During employment and for [NUMBER] months after termination, Employee shall not solicit Employer's customers or employees.
5.2 **Non-Compete** (Check State Law). During employment and for [NUMBER] months after termination, Employee shall not engage in a competing business within [GEOGRAPHIC AREA].

## 6. TERMINATION

Upon termination, Employer shall pay all accrued salary and unused vacation time (if required by state law). Employee shall return all Employer property.

## 7. GOVERNING LAW

This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of [STATE].

---

**SIGNATURES**:

**Employer**:
__________________________
[NAME], [TITLE]

**Employee**:
__________________________
[EMPLOYEE NAME]
```

# Intellectual Property License Agreement Template

## Purpose

This template provides a comprehensive IP License Agreement for licensing intellectual property (trademarks, copyrights, patents, trade secrets) between entities. This is particularly useful for inter-entity licensing within the Empire structure (e.g., ToriMedia licensing IP to operating companies).

**IMPORTANT**: This template must be reviewed and customized by qualified IP counsel before execution. IP-specific terms must be tailored to the licensed property.

## Instructions

1. **Identify Parties**: Replace [LICENSOR] and [LICENSEE] with actual entity names
2. **Define IP**: Complete Schedule A with detailed description of licensed IP
3. **Set Royalty Rate**: Establish arm's-length royalty rate (consult transfer pricing advisor)
4. **Define Scope**: Specify territory, term, and exclusivity provisions
5. **Review Transfer Pricing**: Ensure royalty rate complies with transfer pricing regulations
6. **Customize Terms**: Adjust terms based on specific IP and business needs
7. **Execute**: Have authorized representatives sign the agreement
8. **Record**: Record license with appropriate IP offices (if required)

## Template

```markdown
# INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LICENSE AGREEMENT

**Agreement Date**: [DATE]  
**Effective Date**: [DATE]  
**Agreement Number**: [NUMBER]

## PARTIES

**Licensor** ("Licensor"):  
[LICENSOR ENTITY NAME], LLC  
A [STATE] Limited Liability Company  
Address: [ADDRESS]  
EIN: [EIN]

**Licensee** ("Licensee"):  
[LICENSEE ENTITY NAME], LLC  
A [STATE] Limited Liability Company  
Address: [ADDRESS]  
EIN: [EIN]

---

## RECITALS

WHEREAS, Licensor owns certain intellectual property rights as described in Schedule A attached hereto (the "Licensed IP");

WHEREAS, Licensee desires to obtain a license to use the Licensed IP in connection with its business operations;

WHEREAS, Licensor is willing to grant such license to Licensee on the terms and conditions set forth herein;

NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual covenants and agreements contained herein, the parties agree as follows:

---

## ARTICLE I: DEFINITIONS

### 1.1 Definitions

**"Agreement"** means this Intellectual Property License Agreement, including all Schedules attached hereto.

**"Licensed IP"** means the intellectual property described in Schedule A, including but not limited to trademarks, copyrights, patents, trade secrets, and know-how.

**"Territory"** means [SPECIFY TERRITORY - e.g., "United States", "Worldwide", "North America"].

**"Term"** means the initial term and any renewal terms as set forth in Article VI.

**"Royalty Rate"** means the royalty rate set forth in Article IV.

**"Net Sales"** means [DEFINE NET SALES - typically gross sales less returns, discounts, taxes, shipping].

---

## ARTICLE II: GRANT OF LICENSE

### 2.1 License Grant

Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, Licensor hereby grants to Licensee:

(a) A [NON-EXCLUSIVE/EXCLUSIVE] license to use the Licensed IP in the Territory;

(b) The right to use the Licensed IP in connection with [SPECIFY USE - e.g., "the manufacture, sale, and distribution of products", "the provision of services", "marketing and advertising"];

(c) The right to sublicense the Licensed IP to [SPECIFY SUBLICENSE RIGHTS, IF ANY];

(d) Such other rights as are necessary or appropriate to exercise the license granted herein.

### 2.2 License Scope

The license granted herein includes:

(a) The right to use Licensed IP in connection with Licensee's business operations;

(b) The right to use Licensed IP in advertising and marketing materials;

(c) The right to use Licensed IP on products, packaging, and promotional materials;

(d) [SPECIFY ADDITIONAL RIGHTS].

### 2.3 Restrictions

Licensee shall not:

(a) Use Licensed IP outside the Territory without Licensor's prior written consent;

(b) Use Licensed IP for purposes not authorized in this Agreement;

(c) Modify Licensed IP without Licensor's prior written consent;

(d) Challenge Licensor's ownership of or rights in Licensed IP;

(e) Use Licensed IP in a manner that would damage Licensor's reputation or goodwill;

(f) [SPECIFY ADDITIONAL RESTRICTIONS].

### 2.4 Reservation of Rights

All rights not expressly granted to Licensee are reserved by Licensor. Licensor retains the right to:

(a) Use Licensed IP for its own purposes;

(b) Grant licenses to third parties (if license is non-exclusive);

(c) Enforce Licensed IP against infringers;

(d) Modify or discontinue Licensed IP.

---

## ARTICLE III: LICENSED IP

### 3.1 Description

The Licensed IP is described in detail in Schedule A attached hereto, including:

(a) Trademarks and service marks;

(b) Copyrights;

(c) Patents (if any);

(d) Trade secrets and know-how;

(e) Other intellectual property rights.

### 3.2 Ownership

Licensor represents and warrants that it owns or has the right to license the Licensed IP.

### 3.3 Maintenance

Licensor shall maintain the Licensed IP, including:

(a) Paying maintenance fees (if required);

(b) Filing renewal applications (if required);

(c) Taking action against infringers (at Licensor's discretion);

(d) Maintaining trade secret protection.

### 3.4 Improvements

**Licensor Improvements**: Any improvements to Licensed IP made by Licensor shall remain the property of Licensor.

**Licensee Improvements**: Any improvements to Licensed IP made by Licensee shall be owned by [LICENSOR/LICENSEE/JOINTLY], as specified in Schedule B.

---

## ARTICLE IV: ROYALTIES AND PAYMENTS

### 4.1 Royalty Rate
```

# S-Corporation Election Checklist

## Purpose
This checklist ensures proper S-Corporation election for CXI LLC and ongoing compliance.

## Pre-Election

- [ ] Verify entity eligibility
  - [ ] Domestic corporation or LLC
  - [ ] Single class of stock/membership interests
  - [ ] 100 or fewer shareholders/members
  - [ ] Eligible shareholders/members only
- [ ] Verify shareholder/member eligibility
  - [ ] Individuals, certain trusts, or estates only
  - [ ] No partnerships, corporations, or non-resident aliens
- [ ] Review Operating Agreement
  - [ ] Ensure single class of interests
  - [ ] Verify transfer restrictions
- [ ] Obtain all shareholder/member consents

## Election Filing

- [ ] Prepare Form 2553
  - [ ] Complete all required information
  - [ ] Obtain all consents
  - [ ] Review for accuracy
- [ ] File Form 2553 with IRS
  - [ ] File within 75 days of entity formation OR
  - [ ] File within 75 days of start of tax year
  - [ ] Retain copy of filed form
  - [ ] Confirm receipt

## Post-Election

- [ ] Receive election confirmation from IRS
- [ ] Update entity records
- [ ] Notify shareholders/members
- [ ] Set up S-Corp compliance system

## Ongoing Compliance

### Annual Requirements

- [ ] File Form 1120-S annually
  - [ ] Due by March 15 (or extension)
  - [ ] Provide K-1s to shareholders/members
- [ ] Maintain eligible shareholders/members only
- [ ] Maintain single class of stock/interests
- [ ] Maintain active business operations
- [ ] Monitor compliance monthly

### Quarterly Requirements

- [ ] Review shareholder/member eligibility
- [ ] Review stock/interest structure
- [ ] Assess business activity
- [ ] Monitor compliance

### Monthly Requirements

- [ ] Monitor shareholder/member eligibility
- [ ] Review compliance status
- [ ] Update records as needed

## Reasonable Compensation

- [ ] Conduct compensation analysis annually
  - [ ] Market comparison
  - [ ] Cost approach
  - [ ] Income approach
- [ ] Document compensation decision
- [ ] Set reasonable salary ($60,000-$80,000)
- [ ] Pay salary consistently
- [ ] Document all compensation

## Distribution Planning

- [ ] Plan distributions quarterly
- [ ] Set distribution amounts
- [ ] Document distribution decisions
- [ ] Execute distributions
- [ ] Document distributions
- [ ] Report on K-1s

## Documentation

- [ ] Maintain Form 2553 copy
- [ ] Maintain election confirmation
- [ ] Document compensation analysis
- [ ] Maintain distribution records
- [ ] Retain all tax returns
- [ ] Maintain compliance records

## Notes

- S-election must be filed within 75 days of formation or tax year start
- All shareholders/members must consent
- Must maintain eligibility continuously
- Reasonable compensation is critical for compliance
- Distributions are tax-efficient (no FICA)

# Social Media Post Template

## Purpose

This template provides a framework for creating engaging social media posts across platforms (LinkedIn, Facebook, Instagram, Twitter/X). It ensures consistency and maximizes engagement.

## Instructions

1. **Choose Platform**: Adapt format for specific platform
2. **Craft Hook**: First line must grab attention
3. **Add Value**: Provide useful information or insight
4. **Include CTA**: Tell audience what to do next
5. **Use Hashtags**: Include relevant hashtags (platform-dependent)

## Template Structure

### LinkedIn Post

**Format**: Professional, value-driven, longer form (1,300-3,000 characters)

```markdown
[HOOK - First line that grabs attention]

[VALUE - Share insight, tip, or story]

[ENGAGEMENT - Ask question or invite discussion]

[CTA - Link to article, website, or next step]

#Hashtag1 #Hashtag2 #Hashtag3
```

---

### Facebook Post

**Format**: Conversational, engaging, 40-80 characters for best engagement

```markdown
[HOOK]

[STORY OR VALUE]

[QUESTION TO ENGAGE]

[CTA]

[LINK]
```

---

### Instagram Post

**Format**: Visual-first, concise caption, use emojis sparingly

**Caption**:
```markdown
[HOOK]

[VALUE OR STORY]

[CTA]

#Hashtag1 #Hashtag2 #Hashtag3 #Hashtag4 #Hashtag5
```

**Note**: Instagram allows up to 30 hashtags, but 5-10 is optimal.

---

### Twitter/X Post

**Format**: Concise, punchy, under 280 characters

```markdown
[HOOK]

[VALUE OR INSIGHT]

[CTA OR QUESTION]

[LINK]
```

---

## Post Variations

### Variation 1: Educational Post

**Hook**: "Did you know that [STATISTIC OR FACT]?"

**Body**: "[EXPLANATION OR INSIGHT]"

**CTA**: "What's your experience with this? Share in the comments."

---

### Variation 2: Story Post

**Hook**: "Last week, I [PERSONAL STORY]..."

**Body**: "[LESSON LEARNED OR INSIGHT]"

**CTA**: "Have you had a similar experience?"

---

### Variation 3: Question Post

**Hook**: "What's the biggest challenge you face with [TOPIC]?"

**Body**: "[CONTEXT OR YOUR PERSPECTIVE]"

**CTA**: "Share your thoughts below - I read every comment!"

---

### Variation 4: Value Tip Post

**Hook**: "Here's a quick tip that will [BENEFIT]..."

**Body**: "[TIP OR ADVICE]"

**CTA**: "Save this post for later and follow for more tips!"

---

### Variation 5: Behind-the-Scenes Post

**Hook**: "Ever wonder how we [DO SOMETHING]?"

**Body**: "[BEHIND-THE-SCENES CONTENT]"

**CTA**: "Want to see more? Follow us for daily insights!"

---

## Best Practices

### Content
- **Value First**: Every post should provide value
- **Authentic**: Be genuine and human
- **Consistent**: Maintain brand voice
- **Visual**: Include images or videos when possible

### Timing
- **LinkedIn**: Tuesday-Thursday, 8-10 AM or 12-1 PM
- **Facebook**: Tuesday-Thursday, 1-3 PM
- **Instagram**: Tuesday-Friday, 11 AM-1 PM or 7-9 PM
- **Twitter**: Monday-Friday, 8-9 AM or 12-1 PM

### Engagement
- **Respond**: Reply to comments within 24 hours
- **Ask Questions**: Encourage discussion
- **Tag Relevant**: Tag partners, clients, or industry leaders (when appropriate)
- **Share Others' Content**: Build relationships through sharing

### Hashtags
- **LinkedIn**: 3-5 hashtags
- **Facebook**: 1-2 hashtags
- **Instagram**: 5-10 hashtags
- **Twitter**: 1-2 hashtags

---

## Content Calendar Integration

| Day | Theme | Example Topics |
|-----|-------|----------------|
| Monday | Motivation | Tips, inspiration, week ahead |
| Tuesday | Educational | How-to, industry insights |
| Wednesday | Behind-the-Scenes | Team, process, culture |
| Thursday | Client Success | Case studies, testimonials |
| Friday | Fun/Engagement | Questions, polls, weekend content |

# SOP: Customer Service & Support

## Purpose

This SOP defines the standards and processes for handling customer inquiries, support tickets, and complaints. It ensures a consistent, high-quality experience that fosters customer loyalty.

## Scope

Applies to all team members interacting with customers via email, phone, chat, or ticketing systems.

## Responsibilities

-   **Support Agent**: First-line response and resolution.
-   **Support Manager**: Escalations and quality review.
-   **Product/Service Team**: Technical resolution for complex issues.

## Process Steps

### 1. Ticket Receipt & Triage
-   [ ] **Acknowledge**: Automated receipt email sent immediately.
-   [ ] **Categorize**: Tag ticket by topic (e.g., Billing, Technical, General).
-   [ ] **Prioritize**: Assign priority level (Low, Medium, High, Critical).

### 2. Response
-   **Standard Response Time**: Within [NUMBER] hours.
-   [ ] **Review**: Read customer history and context.
-   [ ] **Respond**: Use templates for common issues but personalize the opening/closing.
-   [ ] **Solve**: Provide clear, step-by-step instructions or resolution.

### 3. Escalation (If needed)
-   **Trigger**: Issue cannot be resolved within [TIME] or requires higher authority.
-   [ ] **Transfer**: Assign to Level 2 Support or Manager.
-   [ ] **Inform**: Notify customer of escalation and expected timeline.

### 4. Resolution & Closure
-   [ ] **Confirm**: Ask customer if the issue is resolved.
-   [ ] **Close**: Mark ticket as "Resolved".
-   [ ] **Feedback**: Send CSAT (Customer Satisfaction) survey.

## Quality Standards

-   **First Response Time (FRT)**: < [NUMBER] hours.
-   **Resolution Time**: < [NUMBER] hours.
-   **CSAT Score**: > 4.5/5.0.
-   **Tone**: Empathetic, professional, and solution-oriented.

## Escalation Matrix

| Severity | Definition | Response Time | Who to Notify |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Critical** | System down, data loss | 15 mins | CTO/Founder |
| **High** | Feature broken, billing error | 2 hours | Support Manager |
| **Medium** | How-to question, minor bug | 24 hours | Support Agent |
| **Low** | Feature request, feedback | 48 hours | Support Agent |

---

**Last Updated**: [DATE]

# SOP: Service Delivery Process

# Monthly Balance Sheet Template

## Purpose

This template provides a comprehensive monthly Balance Sheet for tracking assets, liabilities, and equity. Use this template to monitor financial position and track changes over time.

## Instructions

1. **Select Period**: Enter the month and year for the statement
2. **Enter Assets**: Record all assets by category
3. **Enter Liabilities**: Record all liabilities by category
4. **Calculate Equity**: Calculate equity (Assets - Liabilities)
5. **Verify Balance**: Ensure Assets = Liabilities + Equity
6. **Compare to Prior Period**: Compare to previous month's balance sheet
7. **Review Changes**: Analyze significant changes in account balances
8. **Distribute**: Share with management and stakeholders

Under the terms of the Trust Agreement (Article [Number]), you have the absolute right to withdraw this amount (or a portion thereof) for your own benefit. This withdrawal right will lapse and expire **30 days** from the date of this letter.

# South Dakota Dynasty Trust Agreement Template

## Purpose

This template provides a complete South Dakota Dynasty Trust Agreement for the Legacy Codex. The Dynasty Trust serves as the ultimate parent vault, providing 365-year perpetual wealth preservation, zero state income tax, and top-tier asset protection.

**IMPORTANT**: This template must be reviewed and customized by qualified trust counsel before execution. South Dakota-specific requirements must be verified.

## Instructions

1. **Replace Placeholders**: Replace all bracketed placeholders ([TRUST NAME], [DATE], etc.) with actual information
2. **Review with Attorney**: Have qualified trust attorney review all provisions
3. **State-Specific Provisions**: Verify South Dakota-specific requirements are met
4. **Tax Review**: Have tax advisor review for tax efficiency
5. **Beneficiary Details**: Complete Schedule C with detailed beneficiary information
6. **Asset Schedule**: Complete Schedule A with detailed asset descriptions and values
7. **Trustee Selection**: Confirm all trustee selections and obtain acceptance
8. **Trust Protector**: Designate Trust Protector and document powers
9. **Execution**: Execute with proper notarization and witnesses
10. **Funding**: Complete initial funding and obtain EIN

## Template

```markdown
# SOUTH DAKOTA DYNASTY TRUST AGREEMENT

## TRUST IDENTIFICATION

**Trust Name**: [TRUST NAME] Dynasty Trust  
**Governing Law**: South Dakota  
**Trust Company**: [TRUST COMPANY NAME]  
**Date of Execution**: [DATE]  
**Settlors**: [SETTLOR 1 NAME] and [SETTLOR 2 NAME]  
**EIN**: [EIN NUMBER - OBTAIN AFTER EXECUTION]

---

## ARTICLE I: DECLARATION OF TRUST

### Section 1.1: Trust Creation

The Settlors hereby transfer and assign to the Trustees, in trust, the property described in Schedule A attached hereto (the "Trust Estate"), to be held, administered, and distributed in accordance with the terms of this Agreement.

### Section 1.2: Trust Purpose

This Trust is created for the purpose of:

(a) Preserving and protecting the Trust Estate for the benefit of the Beneficiaries and their descendants for a period of 365 years;

(b) Providing for the health, education, maintenance, and support of the Beneficiaries;

(c) Minimizing estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes;

(d) Protecting the Trust Estate from creditors, lawsuits, and other claims;

(e) Providing for charitable giving through the charitable remainder provisions.

### Section 1.3: Perpetuities Period

Notwithstanding any rule of law to the contrary, this Trust shall continue for a period of 365 years from the date of execution, or until earlier terminated in accordance with the terms hereof.

### Section 1.4: Irrevocability

This Trust is irrevocable. The Settlors retain no powers that would cause the Trust to be included in their estates for estate tax purposes.

---

## ARTICLE II: TRUSTEE ARCHITECTURE

### Section 2.1: Administrative Trustee

The Administrative Trustee shall be [TRUST COMPANY NAME], a South Dakota trust company, or its successor. The Administrative Trustee shall:

(a) Handle all compliance and administrative matters;

(b) Maintain trust records and accounts;

(c) File all required tax returns and reports (Forms 3520, 3520-A, etc.);

(d) Coordinate with other Trustees as necessary;

(e) Provide annual accountings to Beneficiaries;

(f) Maintain records for a minimum of seven years.

**Compensation**: The Administrative Trustee shall be compensated in accordance with its standard fee schedule, which is attached as Schedule D.

### Section 2.2: Investment Trustee

The Investment Trustee shall be [INVESTMENT ADVISOR NAME], or its successor, and shall:

(a) Manage and invest the Trust Estate in accordance with the Investment Policy Statement attached as Schedule B;

(b) Make investment decisions within the parameters set forth in this Agreement and the Investment Policy Statement;

(c) Provide regular investment reports to the Administrative Trustee and Trust Protector (quarterly reports, annual comprehensive reports);

(d) Rebalance investments as necessary to maintain target allocations;

(e) Monitor investment performance against benchmarks.

**Compensation**: The Investment Trustee shall be compensated in accordance with its standard fee schedule.

### Section 2.3: Distribution Trustee

The Distribution Trustee shall be [DISTRIBUTION TRUSTEE NAME], or its successor, and shall:

(a) Make distributions to Beneficiaries in accordance with the HEMS standard set forth in Article IV;

(b) Exercise discretion in determining the amount and timing of distributions;

(c) Consider the needs of all Beneficiaries in making distribution decisions;

(d) Document all distribution decisions in writing;

(e) Maintain records of all distributions made.

**Succession**: Upon resignation, removal, or death of the Distribution Trustee, the successor Distribution Trustee shall be [SUCCESSOR DISTRIBUTION TRUSTEE NAME].

### Section 2.4: Trust Protector

The Trust Protector shall be [TRUST PROTECTOR NAME], or its successor, and shall have the following powers:

(a) Power to remove and replace any Trustee (except the Administrative Trustee) without cause, with or without notice;

(b) Power to modify trust terms to achieve tax efficiency or adapt to changing circumstances, provided such modifications do not violate the rule against perpetuities or change the charitable remainder provisions without court approval;

(c) Power to change the governing law of the Trust (subject to South Dakota law requirements);

(d) Power to add or remove Beneficiaries (subject to limitations set forth in Section 2.5);

(e) Power to veto Trustee decisions that are inconsistent with the Settlors' intent;

(f) Power to direct investment decisions in extraordinary circumstances;

(g) Power to approve or disapprove distributions in excess of HEMS standard;

(h) Power to interpret ambiguous provisions of this Agreement.

**Limitations**: The Trust Protector shall not have the power to:

- Make distributions to himself or herself;

- Modify the charitable remainder provisions without court approval;

- Change the Administrative Trustee without cause and proper documentation;

- Exercise powers in a manner that would cause the Trust to be included in the Settlors' estates;

- Exercise powers in a manner that would cause adverse tax consequences.

**Succession**: Upon resignation, removal, or death of the Trust Protector, the successor Trust Protector shall be [SUCCESSOR TRUST PROTECTOR NAME].

**Liability**: The Trust Protector shall not be liable for any action taken or omitted in good faith, except for gross negligence or willful misconduct.

---

## ARTICLE III: BENEFICIARIES

### Section 3.1: Primary Beneficiaries

The Primary Beneficiaries of this Trust are:

(a) [CHILD 1 NAME] (born [DATE])

(b) [CHILD 2 NAME] (born [DATE])

(c) [CHILD 3 NAME] (born [DATE])

(d) [CHILD 4 NAME] (born [DATE])

Each Primary Beneficiary shall have equal beneficial interests in the Trust Estate.

### Section 3.2: Secondary Beneficiaries

The Secondary Beneficiaries are:

(a) The descendants of each Primary Beneficiary, per stirpes;

(b) The charitable remainder beneficiary as set forth in Article VIII.

### Section 3.3: Beneficiary Sub-Trusts

Each Primary Beneficiary's interest shall be held in a separate sub-trust with the following distribution schedule:

- **Age 25**: 25% of the Beneficiary's share shall be distributed outright to the Beneficiary;

- **Age 30**: 50% of the remaining Beneficiary's share shall be distributed outright to the Beneficiary;

- **Age 35**: 100% of the remaining Beneficiary's share shall be distributed outright to the Beneficiary.

Distributions prior to these ages shall be made only for HEMS purposes as set forth in Article IV.

### Section 3.4: Spendthrift Provisions

No Beneficiary shall have the power to:

(a) Assign, transfer, or encumber his or her interest in the Trust;

(b) Anticipate distributions;

(c) Subject his or her interest to the claims of creditors, except as provided in Section 7.2.

---

## ARTICLE IV: DISTRIBUTION STANDARDS

### Section 4.1: HEMS Standard

Distributions to Beneficiaries shall be made for their health, education, maintenance, and support ("HEMS"). For purposes of this Agreement:

**Health** includes:

- Medical, dental, and mental health expenses (including insurance premiums);

- Wellness and preventive care expenses;

- Long-term care expenses;

- Health-related travel expenses;

- Alternative medicine and therapy expenses.

**Education** includes:

- Tuition, fees, and expenses for primary, secondary, and post-secondary education;

- Educational materials and supplies;

- Study abroad programs;

- Professional development and certification programs;

- Educational travel and experiences;

- Tutoring and educational support services.

**Maintenance** includes:

- Reasonable housing expenses (rent, mortgage payments, property taxes, insurance, maintenance);

- Transportation expenses (vehicle purchase, maintenance, insurance, fuel);

- Food and clothing expenses;

- Utilities and household expenses;

- Personal care and grooming expenses.

**Support** includes:

- Reasonable expenses necessary to maintain the Beneficiary's accustomed standard of living;

- Expenses necessary to support the Beneficiary's dependents;

- Emergency expenses;

- Other expenses necessary for the Beneficiary's support and well-being.

### Section 4.2: Distribution Discretion

The Distribution Trustee shall have absolute discretion in determining:

(a) Whether a distribution qualifies under the HEMS standard;

(b) The amount of any distribution;

(c) The timing of distributions;

(d) Which Beneficiary receives distributions when multiple Beneficiaries have needs;

(e) Whether to make distributions directly to Beneficiaries or to third parties on their behalf.

The Distribution Trustee's decisions shall be final and binding, and shall not be subject to challenge except for abuse of discretion or violation of fiduciary duties.

### Section 4.3: Emergency Distributions

Notwithstanding the HEMS standard, the Distribution Trustee may make distributions for:

(a) Medical emergencies;

(b) Natural disasters affecting the Beneficiary;

(c) Other extraordinary circumstances as determined by the Distribution Trustee in good faith;

(d) Expenses that, while not strictly HEMS, are in the best interests of the Beneficiary and consistent with the Settlors' intent.

### Section 4.4: Substance Abuse Provisions

If the Distribution Trustee determines that a Beneficiary has a substance abuse problem, the Distribution Trustee may:

(a) Require the Beneficiary to undergo treatment as a condition of receiving distributions;

(b) Make distributions directly to treatment providers;

(c) Suspend distributions until the Beneficiary completes treatment;

(d) Make distributions to a third party for the Beneficiary's benefit.

---

## ARTICLE V: INVESTMENT PROVISIONS

### Section 5.1: Investment Authority

The Investment Trustee shall have full authority to invest and reinvest the Trust Estate in any type of property, real or personal, domestic or foreign, including but not limited to:

(a) Stocks, bonds, and other securities (publicly traded and privately held);

(b) Real estate and real estate investments (direct ownership, REITs, partnerships);

(c) Business interests and partnerships (LLCs, corporations, partnerships);

(d) Alternative investments (private equity, hedge funds, commodities);

(e) Cash and cash equivalents;

(f) Life insurance policies (held in sub-trusts);

(g) Intellectual property;

(h) Any other investment permitted by the Investment Policy Statement.

### Section 5.2: Investment Policy Statement

Investments shall be made in accordance with the Investment Policy Statement attached as Schedule B, which may be amended from time to time by the Trust Protector in consultation with the Investment Trustee.

The Investment Policy Statement shall address:

(a) Asset allocation targets;

(b) Risk tolerance;

(c) Time horizon considerations;

(d) Rebalancing triggers and procedures;

(e) Performance benchmarks;

(f) Prohibited investments;

(g) Socially responsible investment guidelines (if any).

### Section 5.3: Prohibited Investments

Notwithstanding Section 5.1, the Trust Estate shall not be invested in:

(a) Collectibles (as defined in Section 408(m) of the Internal Revenue Code), except as part of a diversified portfolio and with Trust Protector approval;

(b) Life insurance policies on the lives of Beneficiaries (except as held in ILIT sub-trusts);

(c) S corporation stock (except through pass-through entities that are not S corporations);

(d) Any investment that would cause the Trust to be treated as a grantor trust (unless such treatment is desired and properly documented);

(e) Investments that violate applicable laws or regulations;

(f) Investments that would cause the Trust to engage in a prohibited transaction under ERISA (if applicable).

### Section 5.4: Investment Performance

The Investment Trustee shall:

(a) Monitor investment performance on at least a quarterly basis;

(b) Compare performance to benchmarks specified in the Investment Policy Statement;

(c) Provide performance reports to the Administrative Trustee and Trust Protector;

(d) Adjust investment strategy as necessary to meet performance objectives.

---

## ARTICLE VI: TRUST ADMINISTRATION

### Section 6.1: Accounting

The Administrative Trustee shall:

(a) Maintain accurate books and records of all Trust transactions;

(b) Provide annual accountings to the Beneficiaries (or their legal guardians if minors);

(c) File all required tax returns (Forms 3520, 3520-A, 1041, etc.);

(d) Maintain records for a minimum of seven years (or as required by law);

(e) Provide accountings upon request by Beneficiaries (subject to reasonable limitations);

(f) Coordinate with other Trustees to ensure complete and accurate records.

### Section 6.2: Tax Elections

The Administrative Trustee, in consultation with tax advisors and with the consent of the Trust Protector, may make any tax elections available to the Trust, including:

(a) Election to treat the Trust as a grantor trust (if applicable and desired);

(b) Section 645 elections (qualified revocable trust);

(c) Fiscal year elections;

(d) Other elections as may be beneficial to the Trust and Beneficiaries.

### Section 6.3: Crummey Notices

If the Trust receives contributions that qualify for the annual gift tax exclusion, the Administrative Trustee shall:

(a) Provide Crummey withdrawal notices to Beneficiaries within the timeframes required by law (typically within 30 days of contribution);

(b) Document that Beneficiaries received notice;

(c) Wait for the withdrawal period to expire before using contributed funds;

(d) Maintain records of all Crummey notices sent.

### Section 6.4: Trustee Compensation

Each Trustee shall be entitled to reasonable compensation for services rendered, which shall be paid from Trust assets. Compensation shall be:

(a) For Administrative Trustee: In accordance with its standard fee schedule;

(b) For Investment Trustee: In accordance with its standard fee schedule or investment management agreement;

(c) For Distribution Trustee: Reasonable compensation as determined by the Trust Protector;

(d) For Trust Protector: Reasonable compensation as determined by agreement or court order (if applicable).

### Section 6.5: Trustee Expenses

All reasonable expenses incurred by Trustees in the administration of the Trust shall be reimbursed from Trust assets, including:

(a) Professional fees (attorneys, accountants, advisors);

(b) Travel expenses;

(c) Office expenses;

(d) Other expenses necessary for Trust administration.

---

## ARTICLE VII: ASSET PROTECTION

### Section 7.1: Spendthrift Provisions

No Beneficiary shall have the power to:

(a) Assign, transfer, or encumber his or her interest in the Trust;

(b) Anticipate distributions;

(c) Subject his or her interest to the claims of creditors, except as provided in Section 7.2.

### Section 7.2: Creditor Protection

The Trust Estate shall be protected from the claims of creditors of the Settlors, Beneficiaries, and Trustees, except:

(a) Claims for child support or alimony (to the extent required by law);

(b) Claims by the United States or any state for taxes (to the extent required by law);

(c) Claims that existed at the time property was transferred to the Trust (subject to applicable statutes of limitations and fraudulent transfer laws);

(d) Claims arising from the Beneficiary's own tortious conduct (to the extent permitted by South Dakota law).

### Section 7.3: Charging Order Protection

If any portion of the Trust Estate is held in a limited liability company or partnership, the Trust provides that creditors of Beneficiaries may only obtain a charging order against the Beneficiary's interest, and may not:

(a) Force distributions;

(b) Participate in management;

(c) Obtain any other remedy against the Trust Estate;

(d) Foreclose on the Beneficiary's interest.

### Section 7.4: Fraudulent Transfer Protection

This Trust is not intended to defraud creditors. All transfers to the Trust are made in good faith and for legitimate estate planning purposes. The Settlors represent that:

(a) They are solvent at the time of each transfer;

(b) They are not transferring assets to avoid existing creditors;

(c) They are retaining sufficient assets to meet their own needs and obligations.

---

## ARTICLE VIII: CHARITABLE REMAINDER

### Section 8.1: Charitable Remainder Beneficiary

Upon termination of this Trust (after 365 years or earlier termination), the remaining Trust Estate shall be distributed to [CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION NAME], a 501(c)(3) organization (EIN: [EIN]), or its successor.

If the designated charitable organization is no longer in existence or no longer qualifies as a 501(c)(3) organization, the Trust Protector (or court if Trust Protector is unable to act) shall select a successor charitable organization with similar purposes.

### Section 8.2: Charitable Purpose

The charitable remainder shall be used for [CHARITABLE PURPOSE], consistent with the Settlors' philanthropic goals and the mission of the charitable organization.

### Section 8.3: Charitable Deduction

The Settlors acknowledge that they may be entitled to a charitable deduction for the present value of the charitable remainder interest, subject to applicable tax laws and regulations.

---

## ARTICLE IX: AMENDMENT AND TERMINATION

### Section 9.1: Amendment

This Trust may be amended by the Trust Protector, subject to:

(a) The amendment must not change the charitable remainder provisions without court approval;

(b) The amendment must not violate the rule against perpetuities (365-year period);

(c) The amendment must be in writing and signed by the Trust Protector;

(d) The amendment must not cause the Trust to be included in the Settlors' estates;

(e) The amendment must not adversely affect the rights of Beneficiaries without their consent (if required by law).

### Section 9.2: Termination

This Trust shall terminate:

(a) Upon expiration of the 365-year perpetuities period;

(b) Upon distribution of all Trust assets;

(c) Upon court order for good cause shown;

(d) Upon written direction of the Trust Protector (subject to limitations and court approval if required);

(e) Upon merger with another trust (if permitted by law and this Agreement).

### Section 9.3: Distribution Upon Termination

Upon termination, the Trust Estate shall be distributed:

(a) First, to Beneficiaries in accordance with their interests as of the termination date;

(b) Second, the remainder to the charitable remainder beneficiary as set forth in Article VIII.

---

## ARTICLE X: GENERAL PROVISIONS

### Section 10.1: Governing Law

This Trust shall be governed by the laws of the State of South Dakota, without regard to conflict of laws principles. The Trust shall be administered in South Dakota.

### Section 10.2: Severability

If any provision of this Agreement is held to be invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect, and the invalid provision shall be modified to the minimum extent necessary to make it valid and enforceable.

### Section 10.3: Headings

Section headings are for convenience only and shall not affect the interpretation of this Agreement.

### Section 10.4: Counterparts

This Agreement may be executed in multiple counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original, and all of which together shall constitute one and the same instrument.

### Section 10.5: Notices

All notices required under this Agreement shall be in writing and delivered:

(a) To Trustees: At their addresses set forth in Schedule E;

(b) To Beneficiaries: At their addresses set forth in Schedule C (or as updated);

(c) To Trust Protector: At the address set forth in Schedule E.

Notices may be delivered in person, by certified mail, or by email (if email address is provided and recipient confirms receipt).

### Section 10.6: Entire Agreement

This Agreement, together with all Schedules attached hereto, constitutes the entire agreement between the parties regarding the Trust and supersedes all prior agreements and understandings.

### Section 10.7: Waiver

No waiver of any provision of this Agreement shall be effective unless in writing and signed by the party waiving such provision.
```

# General Partnership Agreement Template

## Purpose

This template establishes a General Partnership between two or more parties. It outlines capital contributions, profit sharing, management duties, and dissolution procedures.

**IMPORTANT**: Partnerships carry joint and several liability. Legal review is critical.

## Instructions

1.  **Partners**: Identify all partners.
2.  **Capital**: Specify initial contributions.
3.  **Profits/Losses**: Define distribution percentages.
4.  **Management**: Clarify decision-making authority.

```markdown
**Date**: [DATE]

**Partners**:
1. [PARTNER 1 NAME]
2. [PARTNER 2 NAME]

## 1. NAME AND BUSINESS

The name of the partnership shall be [PARTNERSHIP NAME]. The principal business is [BUSINESS DESCRIPTION].

## 2. TERM

The partnership shall commence on [DATE] and continue until dissolved by mutual agreement or operation of law.

## 3. CAPITAL CONTRIBUTIONS

The Partners shall contribute the following capital:
- Partner 1: $[AMOUNT]
- Partner 2: $[AMOUNT]

## 4. PROFIT AND LOSS

Net profits and losses shall be divided as follows:
- Partner 1: [PERCENTAGE]%
- Partner 2: [PERCENTAGE]%

## 5. MANAGEMENT

Each Partner shall have an equal voice in the management of the partnership business. Major decisions require [UNANIMOUS/MAJORITY] consent.

## 6. BANKING

All partnership funds shall be deposited in the partnership's name at [BANK NAME]. Checks require the signature of [NUMBER] Partner(s).

## 7. WITHDRAWAL AND DEATH

In the event of a Partner's withdrawal or death, the remaining Partner(s) shall have the option to purchase the interest of the withdrawing or deceased Partner.

## 8. DISSOLUTION

Upon dissolution, the partnership assets shall be liquidated, debts paid, and remaining surplus distributed to Partners in accordance with their capital accounts.

## 9. DISPUTE RESOLUTION

Any disputes shall be settled by arbitration in [STATE].
```

# Billing Cycle Process Map

## Purpose

This process map outlines the complete billing cycle from invoice generation through payment collection and reconciliation. It ensures consistent cash flow and proper accounting.

## Process Overview

```
Service Delivery → Invoice Generation → Invoice Delivery → Payment Monitoring → Payment Application → Reconciliation → Collections (if needed)
```

## Detailed Process Steps

### Stage 1: Service Delivery Documentation (Ongoing)

**Input**: Services provided

**Activities**:
1. Track billable hours/milestones
2. Document services delivered
3. Record expenses to be reimbursed
4. Update project/service records
5. Verify against contract/agreement

**Output**: Service delivery documented

**Owner**: Service Delivery Team / Project Manager

**Duration**: Ongoing

---

### Stage 2: Invoice Generation (Monthly/Per Project)

**Input**: Service delivery documented

**Activities**:
1. Review billable items for period
2. Verify against contract terms
3. Calculate invoice amounts
4. Generate invoice in accounting system
5. Review invoice for accuracy
6. Attach supporting documentation (if required)

**Output**: Invoice generated and ready

**Owner**: Billing Specialist / Finance Manager

**Duration**: 1-2 days

**Timing**: [SPECIFY - e.g., "By 5th of month for prior month services"]

---

### Stage 3: Invoice Delivery (Day 1)

**Input**: Invoice generated

**Activities**:
1. Send invoice via email to billing contact
2. Attach detailed time logs/receipts (if required)
3. Send copy to account manager (if applicable)
4. Confirm receipt (if automated system)
5. Log invoice in tracking system

**Output**: Invoice delivered to client

**Owner**: Billing Specialist

**Duration**: Same day

---

### Stage 4: Payment Monitoring (Days 1-30)

**Input**: Invoice delivered

**Activities**:
1. Monitor bank feed for incoming payments
2. Check payment tracking system daily
3. Match payments to invoices
4. Identify partial payments
5. Flag overdue invoices

**Output**: Payment status tracked

**Owner**: Finance Manager / Billing Specialist

**Duration**: Ongoing until paid

---

### Stage 5: Payment Application (Upon Receipt)

**Input**: Payment received

**Activities**:
1. Identify which invoice(s) payment applies to
2. Apply payment in accounting system
3. Update invoice status to "Paid"
4. Send payment confirmation to client (if applicable)
5. Update cash flow records

**Output**: Payment applied, invoice closed

**Owner**: Finance Manager

**Duration**: Same day as receipt

---

### Stage 6: Reconciliation (Monthly)

**Input**: Payments applied

**Activities**:
1. Reconcile accounts receivable
2. Verify all payments applied correctly
3. Identify any discrepancies
4. Resolve unmatched payments
5. Generate AR aging report

**Output**: AR reconciled

**Owner**: Finance Manager

**Duration**: 1-2 days (monthly)

---

### Stage 7: Collections (If Overdue)

**Input**: Invoice past due

**Activities**:

**3 Days Past Due**:
1. Send automated reminder email
2. Update invoice status

**15 Days Past Due**:
1. Send personal email from Billing Specialist
2. Call client billing contact
3. Document communication

**30 Days Past Due**:
1. Phone call from Account Manager
2. Discuss payment plan if needed
3. Escalate to management

**60 Days Past Due**:
1. Send formal demand letter
2. Consider service suspension (if contract allows)
3. Legal review if necessary

**90+ Days Past Due**:
1. Legal action or collections agency
2. Write off as bad debt (if appropriate)

**Output**: Payment collected or escalated

**Owner**: Billing Specialist / Account Manager / Management

**Duration**: Varies

---

## Process Metrics

| Metric | Target | Measurement |
|--------|--------|-------------|
| Invoice Accuracy | 100% | % of invoices with no errors |
| Invoice Delivery Time | < 3 days | Days from period end to invoice sent |
| Payment Terms Compliance | > 90% | % of invoices paid on time |
| Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) | < 45 days | Average days to collect payment |
| Collection Rate | > 95% | % of invoices eventually collected |

---

## Decision Points

### Decision 1: Invoice Ready?
- **If Yes**: Proceed to delivery
- **If No**: Resolve issues, then deliver

### Decision 2: Payment Received?
- **If Yes**: Apply payment
- **If No**: Continue monitoring

### Decision 3: Invoice Overdue?
- **If Yes**: Initiate collections process
- **If No**: Continue monitoring

---

## Tools & Systems

- **Accounting Software**: [SYSTEM] - Invoice generation and payment tracking
- **Bank Feed**: [SYSTEM] - Automatic payment detection
- **CRM**: [SYSTEM] - Client information and communication
- **Collections**: [SYSTEM] - Collections tracking and automation

# SOP: Client Onboarding Process

## Purpose

This Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) defines the complete client onboarding process to ensure consistent, professional, and efficient onboarding of new clients across all service lines.

## Scope

This SOP applies to all new client onboarding activities for:
- Notary and RON services
- Transaction coordination services
- Tax and enrolled agent services
- Consulting services
- Other professional services

## Responsibilities

- **Sales/Account Manager**: Initial client contact and qualification
- **Operations Manager**: Process coordination and oversight
- **Client Success Manager**: Onboarding execution and relationship management
- **Administrative Staff**: Document processing and system setup
- **Service Delivery Team**: Service-specific onboarding tasks

## Process Steps

### Phase 1: Pre-Onboarding (Days 1-2)

#### Step 1.1: Contract Execution
- [ ] Receive signed service agreement from client
- [ ] Verify all required signatures and dates
- [ ] Review contract terms and conditions
- [ ] File executed contract in client file
- [ ] Enter contract details into CRM system

#### Step 1.2: Initial Client Information Collection
- [ ] Collect complete client contact information:
  - [ ] Primary contact name and title
  - [ ] Business name (if applicable)
  - [ ] Mailing address
  - [ ] Phone numbers (office, mobile)
  - [ ] Email addresses (primary, secondary)
  - [ ] Preferred communication method
- [ ] Collect billing information:
  - [ ] Billing contact name
  - [ ] Billing address
  - [ ] Payment method preferences
  - [ ] Credit card information (if applicable)
  - [ ] Purchase order requirements (if applicable)
- [ ] Collect service-specific requirements:
  - [ ] Service scope and deliverables
  - [ ] Timeline and deadlines
  - [ ] Special requirements or preferences
  - [ ] Key stakeholders and decision-makers

#### Step 1.3: CRM System Setup
- [ ] Create client record in CRM system
- [ ] Enter all collected client information
- [ ] Assign account manager/client success manager
- [ ] Set up client portal access (if applicable)
- [ ] Create initial project/service record
- [ ] Set up automated workflows and reminders

### Phase 2: Welcome and Introduction (Day 2-3)

#### Step 2.1: Welcome Email
- [ ] Send welcome email within 24 hours of contract execution
- [ ] Include:
  - [ ] Welcome message and introduction
  - [ ] Next steps overview
  - [ ] Key contact information
  - [ ] Client portal login instructions (if applicable)
  - [ ] Onboarding timeline
  - [ ] What to expect in the coming days/weeks

#### Step 2.2: Welcome Package Preparation
- [ ] Prepare welcome package:
  - [ ] Welcome letter
  - [ ] Service overview document
  - [ ] Contact information card
  - [ ] Client portal guide (if applicable)
  - [ ] Service-specific materials
  - [ ] Company brochure/materials
- [ ] Mail or email welcome package to client

#### Step 2.3: Initial Kickoff Call Scheduling
- [ ] Schedule kickoff call within 3-5 business days
- [ ] Send calendar invitation with:
  - [ ] Date and time
  - [ ] Meeting agenda
  - [ ] Video conference link (if applicable)
  - [ ] Preparation materials (if needed)
- [ ] Confirm attendance with all required participants

### Phase 3: Kickoff and Discovery (Day 3-5)

#### Step 3.1: Kickoff Call Execution
- [ ] Conduct kickoff call:
  - [ ] Introductions of team members
  - [ ] Review service agreement and scope
  - [ ] Discuss expectations and goals
  - [ ] Identify key stakeholders
  - [ ] Review communication protocols
  - [ ] Address questions and concerns
- [ ] Document call notes and action items
- [ ] Distribute call summary to all participants

#### Step 3.2: Discovery and Requirements Gathering
- [ ] Conduct service-specific discovery:
  - [ ] Notary Services:
    - [ ] Service volume and frequency
    - [ ] Geographic coverage needs
    - [ ] Preferred scheduling methods
    - [ ] Document types and requirements
  - [ ] Transaction Coordination:
    - [ ] Transaction types and volumes
    - [ ] Timeline requirements
    - [ ] Preferred communication methods
    - [ ] Key contacts and stakeholders
  - [ ] Tax Services:
    - [ ] Tax situation complexity
    - [ ] Document organization preferences
    - [ ] Filing deadlines and requirements
    - [ ] Prior year tax information
  - [ ] Consulting Services:
    - [ ] Project scope and objectives
    - [ ] Timeline and milestones
    - [ ] Resource requirements
    - [ ] Success criteria
- [ ] Document all requirements in client file
- [ ] Create requirements checklist

#### Step 3.3: Service Setup
- [ ] Set up service-specific systems:
  - [ ] Notary Services:
    - [ ] Create client profile in notary system
    - [ ] Set up scheduling preferences
    - [ ] Configure notification settings
  - [ ] Transaction Coordination:
    - [ ] Set up transaction tracking system
    - [ ] Create initial transaction records
    - [ ] Configure workflow automation
  - [ ] Tax Services:
    - [ ] Set up tax software client file
    - [ ] Create document organization system
    - [ ] Set up tax calendar and reminders
  - [ ] Consulting Services:
    - [ ] Set up project management system
    - [ ] Create project plan and timeline
    - [ ] Assign team members and resources
- [ ] Test all systems and access

### Phase 4: Documentation and Compliance (Day 4-7)

#### Step 4.1: Document Collection
- [ ] Request required documents:
  - [ ] Business registration documents (if applicable)
  - [ ] Tax identification numbers
  - [ ] Insurance certificates (if required)
  - [ ] Authorized signatory forms
  - [ ] Service-specific documents
- [ ] Track document receipt and completion
- [ ] Follow up on missing documents

#### Step 4.2: Compliance Verification
- [ ] Verify client information accuracy
- [ ] Complete compliance checks:
  - [ ] KYC (Know Your Customer) verification
  - [ ] Sanctions screening (if applicable)
  - [ ] Credit check (if required)
  - [ ] Insurance verification (if required)
- [ ] Document compliance verification results
- [ ] Address any compliance issues

#### Step 4.3: Internal System Configuration
- [ ] Set up billing and invoicing:
  - [ ] Configure billing schedule
  - [ ] Set up payment terms
  - [ ] Create invoice templates
  - [ ] Test invoice generation
- [ ] Set up reporting:
  - [ ] Configure client reports
  - [ ] Set up report delivery schedule
  - [ ] Test report generation
- [ ] Configure notifications and alerts

### Phase 5: Training and Orientation (Day 5-10)

#### Step 5.1: Client Portal Training (if applicable)
- [ ] Schedule client portal training session
- [ ] Conduct training covering:
  - [ ] Portal login and navigation
  - [ ] Document upload and access
  - [ ] Communication features
  - [ ] Reporting and analytics
  - [ ] Troubleshooting common issues
- [ ] Provide training materials and resources
- [ ] Follow up to ensure understanding

#### Step 5.2: Process Training
- [ ] Train client on service processes:
  - [ ] How to request services
  - [ ] How to submit information/documents
  - [ ] Communication protocols
  - [ ] Timeline expectations
  - [ ] Escalation procedures
- [ ] Provide process documentation
- [ ] Answer questions and address concerns

#### Step 5.3: Team Introduction
- [ ] Introduce client to service delivery team
- [ ] Share team contact information
- [ ] Explain team roles and responsibilities
- [ ] Establish communication preferences

### Phase 6: Service Commencement (Day 7-14)

#### Step 6.1: First Service Delivery
- [ ] Execute first service delivery:
  - [ ] Follow service-specific procedures
  - [ ] Ensure quality standards are met
  - [ ] Document service delivery
  - [ ] Collect client feedback
- [ ] Address any issues immediately
- [ ] Document lessons learned

#### Step 6.2: Initial Check-In
- [ ] Conduct check-in call/meeting within 7 days of first service:
  - [ ] Review first service experience
  - [ ] Address questions or concerns
  - [ ] Confirm satisfaction
  - [ ] Identify any adjustments needed
- [ ] Document feedback and action items
- [ ] Make adjustments as needed

#### Step 6.3: Ongoing Support Setup
- [ ] Establish ongoing communication schedule
- [ ] Set up regular check-in meetings
- [ ] Configure automated status updates
- [ ] Create client success plan

### Phase 7: Onboarding Completion (Day 14-30)

#### Step 7.1: Onboarding Review
- [ ] Conduct onboarding review meeting:
  - [ ] Review all completed steps
  - [ ] Confirm client satisfaction
  - [ ] Address any outstanding items
  - [ ] Plan for ongoing relationship
- [ ] Document onboarding completion

#### Step 7.2: Transition to Ongoing Management
- [ ] Transition from onboarding to ongoing management
- [ ] Update client status in CRM system
- [ ] Set up regular service delivery workflows
- [ ] Schedule next review meeting

#### Step 7.3: Onboarding Survey
- [ ] Send onboarding satisfaction survey
- [ ] Collect feedback on onboarding experience
- [ ] Review feedback and identify improvements
- [ ] Update onboarding process based on feedback

## Quality Standards

- **Timeliness**: Complete onboarding within 14-30 days (depending on service complexity)
- **Communication**: Respond to client inquiries within 24 hours
- **Documentation**: All steps must be documented in CRM system
- **Satisfaction**: Client satisfaction score of 4.5/5.0 or higher
- **Completion**: 100% of required steps completed before service commencement

## Tools and Resources

- CRM System: [SYSTEM NAME]
- Client Portal: [PORTAL NAME]
- Document Management: [SYSTEM NAME]
- Communication Tools: [TOOLS]
- Service-Specific Systems: [SYSTEMS]

## Escalation Procedures

If issues arise during onboarding:

1. **Minor Issues**: Address immediately by onboarding team
2. **Moderate Issues**: Escalate to Operations Manager
3. **Major Issues**: Escalate to Client Success Manager and Account Manager
4. **Critical Issues**: Escalate to senior management

## Process Improvement

- Review onboarding process quarterly
- Collect client feedback on onboarding experience
- Identify bottlenecks and inefficiencies
- Implement process improvements
- Update this SOP as needed

## Related Documents

- Client Service Agreement Template
- Welcome Email Template
- Kickoff Call Agenda Template
- Client Portal User Guide
- Service-Specific Onboarding Checklists
