# Intercompany Loan Agreement Template

## Purpose

This template establishes a formal loan agreement between two related entities (e.g., a holding company and an operating subsidiary). It is critical for documenting the transfer of funds as a loan rather than a capital contribution or income, ensuring tax compliance and preserving the corporate veil.

**IMPORTANT**:
1.  **Interest Rate**: Must use at least the Applicable Federal Rate (AFR) to avoid imputed interest issues.
2.  **Repayment**: Must have a defined schedule or demand provision.
3.  **Documentation**: Actual transfer of funds must match the agreement.

## Instructions

1.  **Identify Parties**: Lender (usually Holding Co) and Borrower (Operating Co).
2.  **Set Amount**: Specify the principal amount.
3.  **Determine Interest**: Check the current IRS AFR for the loan term (Short-term < 3 yrs, Mid-term 3-9 yrs, Long-term > 9 yrs).
4.  **Define Terms**: Set repayment schedule (monthly, quarterly, interest-only, or demand).
5.  **Execute**: Sign and date.

## Template

```markdown
# INTERCOMPANY LOAN PROMISSORY NOTE

**Date**: [DATE]
**Principal Amount**: $[AMOUNT]

**FOR VALUE RECEIVED**, the undersigned, [BORROWER NAME], a [STATE] Limited Liability Company ("Borrower"), promises to pay to the order of [LENDER NAME], a [STATE] Limited Liability Company ("Lender"), the principal sum of [AMOUNT IN WORDS] Dollars ($[AMOUNT]), together with interest on the unpaid principal balance at the rate of [PERCENTAGE]% per annum (the "Interest Rate").

## 1. INTEREST RATE
The Interest Rate shall be fixed at [PERCENTAGE]% per annum, which is equal to or greater than the Applicable Federal Rate (AFR) for [MONTH/YEAR] as published by the IRS. Interest shall be calculated on the basis of a 365-day year.

## 2. REPAYMENT TERMS
Borrower shall repay the principal and interest as follows:

**[OPTION A: Interest Only with Balloon]**
Borrower shall pay accrued interest [MONTHLY/QUARTERLY/ANNUALLY] beginning on [DATE]. The entire unpaid principal balance and any remaining accrued interest shall be due and payable in full on [MATURITY DATE].

**[OPTION B: Amortized Payments]**
Borrower shall make equal [MONTHLY/QUARTERLY] payments of $[AMOUNT] beginning on [DATE] and continuing until [MATURITY DATE], at which time the remaining principal and interest shall be due.

**[OPTION C: Demand Note]**
Principal and accrued interest shall be payable in full upon written demand by Lender.

## 3. PREPAYMENT
Borrower may prepay this Note in whole or in part at any time without penalty. Any partial prepayment shall be applied first to accrued interest and then to principal.

## 4. DEFAULT
Borrower shall be in default if:
(a) Borrower fails to make any payment when due;
(b) Borrower becomes insolvent or files for bankruptcy;
(c) Borrower breaches any other term of this Note.

Upon default, Lender may declare the entire unpaid principal balance and accrued interest immediately due and payable.

## 5. GOVERNING LAW
This Note shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of [STATE].

## 6. WAIVER
Borrower waives presentment, demand, notice of dishonor, and protest.

---

**BORROWER**:

[BORROWER ENTITY NAME]

By: _____________________________
Name: [NAME]
Title: [TITLE]

**LENDER**:

[LENDER ENTITY NAME]

By: _____________________________
Name: [NAME]
Title: [TITLE]
```

**Last Updated**: [DATE]

# Investment Policy Statement (IPS) Template

## Purpose
This document defines the investment goals, risk tolerance, and asset allocation for the Trust. It serves as the "Constitution" for the Investment Trustee.

**Trust Name**: __________________________
**Date Adopted**: __________________________

---

## 1. Investment Objectives
The primary objective of the Trust is **Long-Term Growth and Preservation**.
*   **Time Horizon**: Perpetual (365+ years).
*   **Return Goal**: To exceed the rate of inflation (CPI) by at least 4% annually, net of fees and taxes.

## 2. Risk Tolerance
The Trust has a **High** capacity for risk due to its perpetual time horizon, but a **Moderate** tolerance for volatility.
*   **Acceptable Volatility**: The Trust accepts short-term market fluctuations in exchange for long-term appreciation.
*   **Permanent Loss**: The Trust seeks to avoid permanent impairment of capital (bankruptcy/total loss).

## 3. Asset Allocation Targets

| Asset Class | Target Allocation | Range | Benchmark |
| :--- | :---: | :---: | :--- |
| **Operating Businesses** | 40% | 20-60% | GDP Growth |
| **Real Estate** | 40% | 20-60% | REIT Index |
| **Public Equities** | 15% | 5-25% | S&P 500 |
| **Cash/Equivalents** | 5% | 2-10% | 3-Mo T-Bill |

## 4. Investment Guidelines
*   **Diversification**: No single investment (outside of the Family Business) shall exceed 10% of the total portfolio.
*   **Liquidity**: The Trust shall maintain sufficient liquidity to meet anticipated distributions (HEMS) for 12 months.
*   **Prohibited Assets**: The Trust shall not invest in:
    *   Unregistered securities (without legal review).
    *   Businesses engaged in unethical activities.

## 5. Review and Monitoring
The Investment Trustee shall review the portfolio **Quarterly** and rebalance if allocations drift outside the allowable range.

---

**Adopted By**:

__________________________
[Investment Trustee Name]

# Residential Lease Agreement Template

## Purpose

This template provides a comprehensive residential lease agreement for renting property. It covers rent, security deposit, tenant responsibilities, and landlord rights.

**IMPORTANT**: Landlord-tenant law varies by state. This template must be customized by an attorney familiar with local laws.

## Instructions

1. **Complete Property Details**: Address, unit number, square footage
2. **Set Rent Amount**: Monthly rent and due date
3. **Security Deposit**: Amount and conditions for return
4. **Lease Term**: Start date, end date, renewal options
5. **Tenant Screening**: Reference checks, credit check, income verification
6. **Review with Attorney**: Must be reviewed by qualified counsel

## Template

```markdown
# RESIDENTIAL LEASE AGREEMENT

**Date**: [DATE]
**Lease Number**: [NUMBER]

## PARTIES

**Landlord**: [LANDLORD NAME/ENTITY]
Address: [ADDRESS]
Phone: [PHONE]
Email: [EMAIL]

**Tenant(s)**: [TENANT NAME(S)]
Address: [ADDRESS]
Phone: [PHONE]
Email: [EMAIL]

**Property Type**: [APARTMENT / HOUSE / CONDO / etc.]

### 1. Term

This Lease shall commence on [START DATE] and continue until [END DATE] (the "Lease Term").

### 2. Renewal

At the end of the Lease Term, this Lease shall:
- [ ] Automatically renew month-to-month unless either party gives [NUMBER] days' written notice
- [ ] Terminate unless renewed by written agreement
- [ ] [OTHER RENEWAL PROVISION]

---

## RENT AND PAYMENTS

### 3. Monthly Rent

Tenant shall pay monthly rent of **$[AMOUNT]** per month, due on the [DAY] of each month.

### 4. Late Fees

If rent is not received by the [DAY] of the month, Tenant shall pay a late fee of **$[AMOUNT]** or [PERCENTAGE]% of monthly rent, whichever is greater.

### 5. Payment Method

Rent shall be paid by:
- [ ] Check mailed to [ADDRESS]
- [ ] Electronic transfer to [ACCOUNT]
- [ ] Online portal at [URL]
- [ ] [OTHER METHOD]

### 6. Security Deposit

Tenant has paid a security deposit of **$[AMOUNT]** which shall be held by Landlord and returned within [NUMBER] days after termination, less any deductions for:
- Unpaid rent
- Damage beyond normal wear and tear
- Cleaning costs (if property not left clean)
- Other charges permitted by law

---

## USE AND OCCUPANCY

### 7. Permitted Use

The Property shall be used solely as a private residence for Tenant and the following occupants:
- [LIST OCCUPANTS - names and relationship]

**Maximum Occupancy**: [NUMBER] persons

### 8. Prohibited Activities

Tenant shall not:
- Use Property for any illegal purpose
- Disturb neighbors or violate noise ordinances
- Keep pets without written permission (if applicable)
- Smoke in the Property (if non-smoking property)
- Make alterations without written consent
- Sublet or assign without written consent

---

## TENANT OBLIGATIONS

### 9. Maintenance and Repairs

Tenant shall:
- Keep Property clean and sanitary
- Dispose of trash properly
- Maintain plumbing fixtures
- Replace light bulbs and batteries
- Maintain smoke detectors
- Report needed repairs promptly
- [OTHER MAINTENANCE OBLIGATIONS]

### 10. Utilities

Tenant shall pay for:
- [ ] Electricity
- [ ] Gas
- [ ] Water/Sewer
- [ ] Trash
- [ ] Internet/Cable
- [OTHER UTILITIES]

Landlord shall pay for: [LIST LANDLORD-PAID UTILITIES]

### 11. Insurance

Tenant is required to maintain renter's insurance with minimum coverage of $[AMOUNT] for personal property and liability.

---

## LANDLORD OBLIGATIONS

### 12. Habitability

Landlord shall maintain Property in habitable condition and comply with all building codes and health regulations.

### 13. Repairs

Landlord shall make necessary repairs to maintain habitability, including:
- Structural repairs
- Plumbing, electrical, and HVAC systems
- Appliances provided by Landlord
- [OTHER REPAIRS]

### 14. Entry

Landlord may enter Property:
- With [NUMBER] hours' notice for inspections, repairs, or showings
- In case of emergency without notice
- At reasonable times for other purposes permitted by law

---

## DEFAULT AND TERMINATION

### 15. Tenant Default

Tenant shall be in default if:
- Rent is not paid when due
- Tenant violates any term of this Lease
- Tenant abandons the Property
- Tenant engages in illegal activity

### 16. Remedies

Upon default, Landlord may:
- Terminate this Lease
- Evict Tenant
- Recover unpaid rent and damages
- Exercise other remedies available at law

### 17. Early Termination

If Tenant terminates early:
- Tenant shall pay rent until Property is re-rented or Lease Term ends
- Tenant shall pay reasonable re-leasing costs
- Security deposit may be forfeited

---

## GENERAL PROVISIONS

### 18. Entire Agreement

This Lease constitutes the entire agreement between the parties.
```

# Real Estate Property Analysis Worksheet

## Purpose

This template helps evaluate real estate investment opportunities by calculating key metrics like cash flow, ROI, cap rate, and cash-on-cash return. Use this before making any property purchase decision.

## Instructions

1. **Gather Data**: Collect all property and financial information
2. **Enter Income**: List all revenue sources
3. **Enter Expenses**: List all operating expenses
4. **Calculate Metrics**: Use formulas to determine profitability
5. **Compare**: Compare to other investment opportunities
6. **Decision**: Use metrics to make informed investment decision

## Template

```markdown
# REAL ESTATE PROPERTY ANALYSIS WORKSHEET

**Property Address**: [ADDRESS]
**Analysis Date**: [DATE]
**Analyzed By**: [NAME]

---

## PROPERTY INFORMATION

| Item | Value |
|------|-------|
| Property Type | [SINGLE FAMILY / MULTI-FAMILY / COMMERCIAL] |
| Square Footage | [NUMBER] sq ft |
| Year Built | [YEAR] |
| Lot Size | [NUMBER] acres/sq ft |
| Number of Units | [NUMBER] |
| Number of Bedrooms | [NUMBER] |
| Number of Bathrooms | [NUMBER] |

---

## PURCHASE INFORMATION

| Item | Amount |
|------|--------|
| Purchase Price | $[AMOUNT] |
| Down Payment | $[AMOUNT] ([PERCENTAGE]%) |
| Loan Amount | $[AMOUNT] |
| Interest Rate | [PERCENTAGE]% |
| Loan Term | [NUMBER] years |
| Monthly Payment (P&I) | $[AMOUNT] |
| Closing Costs | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Total Cash Required** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

---

## INCOME ANALYSIS

### Monthly Rental Income

| Unit/Type | Monthly Rent | Annual Rent |
|-----------|--------------|-------------|
| Unit 1 | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Unit 2 | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Parking/Storage | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Other Income | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Total Monthly Income** | **$[AMOUNT]** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

### Vacancy Allowance

| Item | Amount |
|------|--------|
| Annual Income | $[AMOUNT] |
| Vacancy Rate | [PERCENTAGE]% |
| **Vacancy Allowance** | **($[AMOUNT])** |
| **Effective Gross Income** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

---

## EXPENSE ANALYSIS

### Operating Expenses (Monthly)

| Category | Monthly | Annual |
|----------|---------|--------|
| Property Management | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Property Taxes | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Insurance | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Maintenance/Repairs | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Utilities (if paid by owner) | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| HOA Fees | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Landscaping | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Advertising/Marketing | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Legal/Accounting | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Reserves (CapEx) | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Total Operating Expenses** | **$[AMOUNT]** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

### Debt Service

| Item | Monthly | Annual |
|------|---------|--------|
| Principal & Interest | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Total Debt Service** | **$[AMOUNT]** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

---

## CASH FLOW ANALYSIS

| Item | Monthly | Annual |
|------|---------|--------|
| Effective Gross Income | $[AMOUNT] | $[AMOUNT] |
| Less: Operating Expenses | ($[AMOUNT]) | ($[AMOUNT]) |
| **Net Operating Income (NOI)** | **$[AMOUNT]** | **$[AMOUNT]** |
| Less: Debt Service | ($[AMOUNT]) | ($[AMOUNT]) |
| **Cash Flow** | **$[AMOUNT]** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

---

## KEY METRICS

### Return on Investment (ROI)

**ROI** = (Annual Cash Flow / Total Cash Invested) × 100
**ROI** = ($[AMOUNT] / $[AMOUNT]) × 100 = **[PERCENTAGE]%**

### Capitalization Rate (Cap Rate)

**Cap Rate** = (Net Operating Income / Purchase Price) × 100
**Cap Rate** = ($[AMOUNT] / $[AMOUNT]) × 100 = **[PERCENTAGE]%**

### Cash-on-Cash Return

**Cash-on-Cash** = (Annual Cash Flow / Total Cash Invested) × 100
**Cash-on-Cash** = ($[AMOUNT] / $[AMOUNT]) × 100 = **[PERCENTAGE]%**

### Debt Service Coverage Ratio (DSCR)

**DSCR** = Net Operating Income / Annual Debt Service
**DSCR** = $[AMOUNT] / $[AMOUNT] = **[RATIO]**

*(DSCR > 1.0 indicates positive cash flow)*

### Gross Rent Multiplier (GRM)

**GRM** = Purchase Price / Annual Gross Rent
**GRM** = $[AMOUNT] / $[AMOUNT] = **[MULTIPLIER]**

---

## BREAK-EVEN ANALYSIS

**Break-Even Occupancy** = (Operating Expenses + Debt Service) / Gross Income
**Break-Even Occupancy** = ($[AMOUNT] + $[AMOUNT]) / $[AMOUNT] = **[PERCENTAGE]%**

---

## APPRECIATION ANALYSIS

| Item | Value |
|------|-------|
| Current Value | $[AMOUNT] |
| Projected Annual Appreciation | [PERCENTAGE]% |
| Projected Value in 5 Years | $[AMOUNT] |
| Projected Value in 10 Years | $[AMOUNT] |

---

## TAX BENEFITS (ESTIMATED)

| Item | Annual Amount |
|------|---------------|
| Depreciation Deduction | $[AMOUNT] |
| Interest Deduction | $[AMOUNT] |
| Property Tax Deduction | $[AMOUNT] |
| Other Deductions | $[AMOUNT] |
| **Total Tax Benefits** | **$[AMOUNT]** |

---

- [STRENGTH 1]
- [STRENGTH 2]
- [STRENGTH 3]

### Concerns
- [CONCERN 1]
- [CONCERN 2]
- [CONCERN 3]

### Recommendation

[ ] **BUY** - Meets investment criteria
[ ] **PASS** - Does not meet investment criteria
[ ] **NEGOTIATE** - Counteroffer at $[AMOUNT]

**Reasoning**: [EXPLANATION OF DECISION]

---
```

# Client Acquisition Workflow

## Purpose

This workflow defines the end-to-end process for acquiring new clients, from initial lead generation through contract signing and onboarding. It ensures consistency and maximizes conversion rates.

## Scope

Applies to all sales and business development activities for [COMPANY NAME].

## Workflow Steps

### Phase 1: Lead Generation

1. **Lead Sources**
   - [ ] Inbound marketing (website, SEO, content)
   - [ ] Outbound prospecting (cold calls, emails)
   - [ ] Referrals from existing clients
   - [ ] Networking events and conferences
   - [ ] Partnerships and alliances

2. **Lead Capture**
   - [ ] Lead enters CRM system
   - [ ] Lead source tagged
   - [ ] Initial lead score assigned
   - [ ] Automated welcome email sent

### Phase 2: Qualification

1. **Initial Contact**
   - [ ] Sales rep assigned (if not automated)
   - [ ] Initial outreach within [NUMBER] hours
   - [ ] Discovery call scheduled

2. **Discovery Call**
   - [ ] Understand prospect's needs
   - [ ] Identify decision-makers
   - [ ] Assess budget and timeline
   - [ ] Determine fit with services
   - [ ] **Qualification Criteria**:
     - [ ] Has need/problem we solve
     - [ ] Has budget
     - [ ] Has authority to buy
     - [ ] Has timeline

3. **Qualification Decision**
   - **Qualified**: Proceed to Phase 3
   - **Not Qualified**: Nurture in marketing sequence or disqualify

### Phase 3: Proposal & Presentation

1. **Proposal Development**
   - [ ] Customize proposal template
   - [ ] Include specific solution for prospect
   - [ ] Set pricing and terms
   - [ ] Prepare presentation materials

2. **Proposal Delivery**
   - [ ] Send proposal via email
   - [ ] Schedule presentation meeting (if needed)
   - [ ] Follow up within [NUMBER] days

3. **Presentation (if required)**
   - [ ] Present solution
   - [ ] Address questions and objections
   - [ ] Discuss next steps

### Phase 4: Negotiation & Closing

1. **Handle Objections**
   - [ ] Listen to concerns
   - [ ] Address each objection
   - [ ] Provide additional information if needed

2. **Negotiate Terms**
   - [ ] Discuss pricing (if needed)
   - [ ] Adjust scope (if needed)
   - [ ] Finalize contract terms

3. **Close**
   - [ ] Send final contract
   - [ ] Obtain signatures
   - [ ] Confirm receipt of signed contract
   - [ ] Celebrate win!

### Phase 5: Onboarding Handoff

1. **Internal Handoff**
   - [ ] Notify operations team
   - [ ] Transfer client information to CRM
   - [ ] Schedule kickoff meeting
   - [ ] Assign account manager

2. **Client Onboarding**
   - [ ] Send welcome email
   - [ ] Schedule kickoff call
   - [ ] Begin onboarding process (see Client Onboarding SOP)

---

## Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)

| Metric | Target | Measurement |
|--------|--------|-------------|
| Lead Response Time | < 2 hours | Average time to first contact |
| Qualification Rate | > 30% | % of leads that become qualified |
| Proposal Acceptance Rate | > 25% | % of proposals that close |
| Sales Cycle Length | < [NUMBER] days | Average days from lead to close |
| Cost Per Acquisition | < $[AMOUNT] | Total sales costs / new clients |

---

## Tools & Systems

- **CRM**: [SYSTEM NAME] - Lead tracking and pipeline management
- **Email**: [SYSTEM NAME] - Email sequences and templates
- **Proposals**: [SYSTEM NAME] - Proposal generation and tracking
- **Contracts**: [SYSTEM NAME] - Contract management and e-signatures

---

## Common Objections & Responses

### "We don't have budget"
**Response**: "I understand budget is always a consideration. What would need to happen for this to become a priority? What's the cost of not addressing [THEIR PROBLEM]?"

### "We need to think about it"
**Response**: "I understand you want to think it over. What specific questions or concerns do you have that I can address?"

### "Your price is too high"
**Response**: "I understand price is important. Let me show you the ROI - [CLIENT NAME] achieved [RESULT] which saved them $[AMOUNT]. What would that kind of result be worth to you?"

---

**Last Updated**: [DATE]  
**Next Review**: [DATE + 3 MONTHS]

# Business Valuation Worksheet

## Purpose

This template helps estimate the value of a business using multiple valuation methods. It's useful for buying/selling businesses, estate planning, or strategic planning.

## Instructions

1. **Gather Financials**: Collect 3-5 years of financial statements
2. **Calculate Metrics**: Compute key financial ratios and multiples
3. **Apply Methods**: Use multiple valuation methods
4. **Reconcile**: Average or weight different methods
5. **Document Assumptions**: Record all assumptions used

Just a heads up—we had over [Number] visitors looking for [Service] last month. If your profile isn't claimed, those leads might be going to your competitors.

Claiming your listing ensures you show up in search results.

[Link: Claim My Listing]

Best,
[Your Name]

Thanks,
[Your Name]

# Property Management Agreement Template

## Purpose

This agreement establishes the relationship between a property owner and a property management company (or individual manager). It defines the manager's authority, duties, and compensation.

## Instructions

1.  **Authority**: Define what the manager can do (sign leases, spend money on repairs).
2.  **Fees**: Specify management fees (usually % of rent) and other fees (leasing fee, renewal fee).
3.  **Spending Limit**: Set a cap on repair costs the manager can authorize without owner approval.

## Template

```markdown
# PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT

**Date**: [DATE]

**Owner**: [OWNER NAME/ENTITY]
**Manager**: [MANAGEMENT COMPANY NAME]

**1. APPOINTMENT**
Owner appoints Manager as the exclusive agent to manage, lease, and operate the property located at:
[PROPERTY ADDRESS] (the "Property").

**2. TERM**
This Agreement shall commence on [START DATE] and continue for [NUMBER] year(s). It shall automatically renew unless terminated by either party with [NUMBER] days' written notice.

**3. MANAGER'S RESPONSIBILITIES**
Manager agrees to:
(a) Market the Property and screen prospective tenants.
(b) Execute leases and renewals on Owner's behalf.
(c) Collect rents and security deposits.
(d) Coordinate maintenance and repairs.
(e) Maintain accurate financial records and provide monthly reports to Owner.
(f) Handle tenant relations and evictions (if necessary).

**4. OWNER'S RESPONSIBILITIES**
Owner agrees to:
(a) Maintain property insurance (liability and hazard).
(b) Provide funds for necessary repairs and operating expenses.
(c) Indemnify Manager against claims arising from the Property (except for Manager's negligence).

**5. COMPENSATION**
Owner shall pay Manager:
-   **Management Fee**: [PERCENTAGE]% of gross monthly rent collected.
-   **Leasing Fee**: $[AMOUNT] or [PERCENTAGE]% of first month's rent for new tenant placement.
-   **Renewal Fee**: $[AMOUNT] for lease renewals.

**6. EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENT**
Manager may pay operating expenses from collected rents. If expenses exceed income, Owner shall reimburse Manager within [NUMBER] days.

**7. SPENDING AUTHORITY**
Manager is authorized to spend up to $[AMOUNT] for any single repair or maintenance item without prior Owner approval.
*Exception*: Emergency repairs necessary to protect the Property or tenant safety do not require prior approval.

**8. BANKING**
Manager shall hold all security deposits in a separate escrow account in compliance with state law. Rents shall be deposited into a trust account.

**9. TERMINATION**
Upon termination, Manager shall transfer all records, funds, and keys to Owner within [NUMBER] days.

**10. GOVERNING LAW**
This Agreement is governed by the laws of the State of [STATE].

---

**SIGNATURES**:

**Owner**:
__________________________
[NAME]
Date: __________

**Manager**:
__________________________
[NAME]
Date: __________
```

---
**Version**: 1.0
**Last Updated**: [DATE]

# Residential Real Estate Purchase Agreement Template

## Purpose

This template provides a standard residential purchase agreement for buying real estate. It covers all essential terms including price, contingencies, closing date, and property condition.

**IMPORTANT**: Real estate purchase agreements are highly state-specific. This template must be customized by a real estate attorney familiar with local laws.

## Instructions

1. **Complete Property Details**: Legal description, address, parcel number
2. **Set Purchase Price**: Total price and earnest money deposit
3. **Define Contingencies**: Inspection, financing, appraisal, title
4. **Set Closing Date**: Target closing date and possession date
5. **Specify Terms**: Financing terms if applicable
6. **Review with Attorney**: Must be reviewed by qualified real estate counsel

## Template

```markdown
# RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE PURCHASE AGREEMENT

**Date**: [DATE]
**Agreement Number**: [NUMBER]

## PARTIES

**Buyer**: [BUYER NAME(S)]
Address: [ADDRESS]
Phone: [PHONE]
Email: [EMAIL]

**Seller**: [SELLER NAME(S)]
Address: [ADDRESS]
Phone: [PHONE]
Email: [EMAIL]

---

## PROPERTY DESCRIPTION

**Property Address**: [STREET ADDRESS], [CITY], [STATE] [ZIP]

**Legal Description**: [LEGAL DESCRIPTION FROM DEED]

**Parcel Number**: [PARCEL/TAX ID NUMBER]

**Property Type**: [SINGLE FAMILY / CONDO / TOWNHOME / etc.]

---

## PURCHASE PRICE AND TERMS

### 1. Purchase Price

The total purchase price for the Property is **$[AMOUNT]** (the "Purchase Price").

### 2. Earnest Money Deposit

Buyer shall deposit earnest money in the amount of **$[AMOUNT]** with [ESCROW COMPANY/TITLE COMPANY] within [NUMBER] days of execution of this Agreement.

### 3. Down Payment

Buyer's down payment shall be **$[AMOUNT]** or [PERCENTAGE]% of the Purchase Price.

### 4. Financing

Buyer's obligation to purchase is [CONTINGENT/NOT CONTINGENT] upon obtaining financing:

- **Loan Amount**: $[AMOUNT]
- **Loan Type**: [CONVENTIONAL / FHA / VA / CASH / etc.]
- **Interest Rate**: Not to exceed [PERCENTAGE]%
- **Loan Term**: [NUMBER] years
- **Financing Contingency Period**: [NUMBER] days from execution

### 5. Closing Costs

[SPECIFY WHO PAYS CLOSING COSTS - typically split between buyer and seller per local custom]

---

## CONTINGENCIES

### 6. Inspection Contingency

Buyer has [NUMBER] days from execution to conduct inspections. If Buyer is not satisfied with inspection results, Buyer may:
- Terminate this Agreement and receive full refund of earnest money, OR
- Request repairs (Seller may accept, reject, or counter)

### 7. Appraisal Contingency

If property does not appraise for at least the Purchase Price, Buyer may:
- Terminate and receive earnest money refund, OR
- Proceed with purchase at appraised value (if Seller agrees)

### 8. Title Contingency

Seller shall provide marketable title free of liens and encumbrances except:
- [LIST PERMITTED EXCEPTIONS - e.g., easements, restrictions]

### 9. Home Sale Contingency (if applicable)

Buyer's obligation is contingent upon sale of Buyer's current property at [ADDRESS] by [DATE].

---

## CLOSING AND POSSESSION

### 10. Closing Date

The closing shall occur on or before [DATE] (the "Closing Date").

### 11. Possession

Possession of the Property shall be delivered to Buyer:
- [ ] At closing
- [ ] [NUMBER] days after closing
- [ ] [SPECIFIC DATE]

### 12. Prorations

Property taxes, HOA fees, and utilities shall be prorated as of the Closing Date.

---

## PROPERTY CONDITION

### 13. "As-Is" Sale (if applicable)

Property is sold "as-is" with no warranties except as required by law.

### 14. Seller Disclosures

Seller shall provide:
- Property condition disclosure
- Lead-based paint disclosure (if built before 1978)
- HOA documents (if applicable)
- Other disclosures required by law

---

## DEFAULT AND REMEDIES

### 15. Buyer Default

If Buyer defaults, Seller may:
- Retain earnest money as liquidated damages
- Pursue specific performance
- Seek other remedies available at law

### 16. Seller Default

If Seller defaults, Buyer may:
- Seek specific performance
- Recover damages
- Terminate and receive earnest money refund

---

## GENERAL PROVISIONS

### 17. Entire Agreement

This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the parties.

### 18. Governing Law

This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of [STATE].

### 19. Counterparts

This Agreement may be executed in counterparts, including electronic signatures.

---

## SIGNATURES

**BUYER**:

_____________________________
[BUYER NAME]
Date: _______________

_____________________________
[BUYER NAME] (if joint)
Date: _______________

**SELLER**:

_____________________________
[SELLER NAME]
Date: _______________

_____________________________
[SELLER NAME] (if joint)
Date: _______________

**WITNESSES** (if required by state law):

_____________________________
[WITNESS 1]
Date: _______________

_____________________________
[WITNESS 2]
Date: _______________

---

## ADDENDA AND EXHIBITS

- [ ] Addendum A: Property Condition Disclosure
- [ ] Addendum B: Lead-Based Paint Disclosure
- [ ] Addendum C: HOA Documents
- [ ] Addendum D: [OTHER ADDENDA]

---

*This template is version 1.0 and was created for the Legacy Codex. All legal templates must be reviewed by qualified counsel before use.*
```

- **State-Specific**: Real estate law varies significantly by state. This template must be customized for your state.

# Values Transmission Curriculum Template
## Age-Appropriate Education Program

Use this template to design your family's values transmission curriculum.

**Family Name**: _______________

**Date Created**: _______________

---

## Phase 1: Foundation (Ages 5-10)

### Curriculum Goals

**Primary Focus**: Work Ethic & Basic Money Concepts

**Learning Objectives**:
1. Understand needs vs. wants
2. Learn that money comes from work
3. Practice saving and spending
4. Develop basic work ethic

---

### Curriculum Content

**Unit 1: Needs vs. Wants**
- **Concepts**: 
  - Needs are necessary (food, shelter, clothing)
  - Wants are nice to have (toys, games, treats)
  - We prioritize needs over wants
- **Activities**:
  - Sorting game (needs vs. wants)
  - Shopping exercises
  - Discussion of choices
- **Assessment**: Can child distinguish needs from wants?

---

**Unit 2: Earning Money**
- **Concepts**:
  - Money comes from creating value
  - Work creates value
  - Value creation is rewarded
- **Activities**:
  - Chore system with payment
  - Value creation games
  - Family business exposure
- **Assessment**: Does child understand money comes from work?

---

**Unit 3: Saving vs. Spending**
- **Concepts**:
  - Money can be saved for future goals
  - Money can be spent immediately
  - Saving allows larger purchases
- **Activities**:
  - Three Jars system (Save 50%, Spend 40%, Give 10%)
  - Savings goal setting
  - Tracking savings progress
- **Assessment**: Is child saving money regularly?

---

**Unit 4: Work Ethic**
- **Concepts**:
  - Hard work leads to rewards
  - Effort matters
  - Completing tasks is important
- **Activities**:
  - Age-appropriate chores
  - Task completion tracking
  - Effort recognition
- **Assessment**: Does child complete chores without excessive prompting?

# Wyoming LLC Operating Agreement Template

## Purpose

This template provides a comprehensive Operating Agreement for Wyoming Limited Liability Companies. This agreement governs the operations, management, ownership, and administration of the LLC.

**IMPORTANT**: This template must be reviewed and customized by qualified business counsel before execution. Wyoming-specific requirements must be verified.

## Instructions

1. **Complete Company Information**: Fill in all company details
2. **Identify Members**: List all members and their ownership percentages
3. **Define Management**: Choose manager-managed or member-managed structure
4. **Set Capital Contributions**: Document initial and future contributions
5. **Establish Distribution Provisions**: Define profit/loss allocation
6. **Customize Terms**: Adjust terms based on specific business needs
7. **Execute**: Have all members sign the agreement
8. **File**: Keep with company records (not filed with state)

## Template

```markdown
# OPERATING AGREEMENT OF [LLC NAME], LLC

## COMPANY INFORMATION

**Company Name**: [LLC NAME], LLC  
**State of Formation**: Wyoming  
**Formation Date**: [DATE]  
**Principal Office**: [ADDRESS]  
**Mailing Address**: [ADDRESS] (if different)  
**Registered Agent**: [REGISTERED AGENT NAME]  
**Registered Agent Address**: [ADDRESS]  
**EIN**: [EIN NUMBER]

---

## ARTICLE I: ORGANIZATION

### Section 1.1: Formation

The Company was formed as a Wyoming limited liability company on [DATE] by filing Articles of Organization with the Wyoming Secretary of State.

### Section 1.2: Name

The name of the Company is [LLC NAME], LLC. The Company may conduct business under this name or any other name approved by the Members in accordance with this Agreement.

### Section 1.3: Purpose

The purpose of the Company is to:

(a) [PRIMARY BUSINESS PURPOSE - e.g., "Provide management, administrative, and business services"];

(b) Engage in any lawful business activity permitted under Wyoming law;

(c) Own, manage, and operate businesses and assets;

(d) Make investments;

(e) Engage in any other activities related or incidental to the foregoing.

### Section 1.4: Term

The Company shall continue in existence until dissolved in accordance with this Agreement or by operation of law.

### Section 1.5: Principal Office

The principal office of the Company shall be located at [ADDRESS], or at such other location as the Members may determine.

---

## ARTICLE II: MEMBERSHIP

### Section 2.1: Initial Members

The initial Members of the Company are:

| Member Name | Membership Interest | Units |
|-------------|-------------------|-------|
| [MEMBER 1 NAME] | [PERCENTAGE]% | [NUMBER] |
| [MEMBER 2 NAME] | [PERCENTAGE]% | [NUMBER] |
| **Total** | **100%** | **[TOTAL UNITS]** |

### Section 2.2: Membership Interests

Membership interests are represented by Units. The total number of Units authorized is [NUMBER], with each Unit representing a [PERCENTAGE]% interest in the Company.

### Section 2.3: Capital Contributions

**Initial Capital Contributions**:

| Member | Contribution Amount | Contribution Type | Units Received |
|--------|-------------------|------------------|----------------|
| [MEMBER 1] | $[AMOUNT] | [CASH/PROPERTY/SERVICES] | [NUMBER] |
| [MEMBER 2] | $[AMOUNT] | [CASH/PROPERTY/SERVICES] | [NUMBER] |
| **Total** | **$[TOTAL]** | | **[TOTAL UNITS]** |

### Section 2.4: Additional Contributions

Additional capital contributions may be made only with the unanimous consent of all Members, unless otherwise provided in this Agreement.

### Section 2.5: Return of Contributions

No Member shall be entitled to the return of any capital contribution except:

(a) Upon dissolution and winding up of the Company;

(b) As otherwise provided in this Agreement;

(c) With the consent of all Members.

### Section 2.6: Transfer Restrictions

No Member may transfer his or her membership interest without the written consent of Members holding a majority of the membership interests, except:

(a) Transfers to family members or trusts for family members (with notice);

(b) Transfers to entities controlled by the Member (with notice);

(c) Transfers required by law or court order;

(d) Transfers in connection with a buy-sell agreement.

### Section 2.7: Admission of New Members

New Members may be admitted only with the consent of Members holding a majority of the membership interests and upon:

(a) Execution of this Agreement or a joinder agreement;

(b) Making required capital contribution;

(c) Payment of any required admission fees.

---

## ARTICLE III: MANAGEMENT

### Section 3.1: Management Structure

The Company shall be managed by [MANAGER-MANAGED/MEMBER-MANAGED].

### Section 3.2: Manager-Managed Provisions

[IF MANAGER-MANAGED]:

(a) The Company shall be managed by one or more Managers;

(b) The initial Manager(s) shall be: [MANAGER NAME(S)];

(c) Managers shall be elected by Members holding a majority of membership interests;

(d) Managers may be removed by Members holding a majority of membership interests, with or without cause;

(e) Managers need not be Members;

(f) Managers shall serve until resignation, removal, or death;

(g) Vacancies shall be filled by Members holding a majority of membership interests.

### Section 3.3: Member-Managed Provisions

[IF MEMBER-MANAGED]:

(a) All Members shall participate in management;

(b) Decisions shall be made by Members holding a majority of membership interests (unless this Agreement requires a different vote);

(c) Day-to-day operations may be delegated to officers or employees;

(d) Each Member has equal voting rights regardless of ownership percentage (unless otherwise provided).

### Section 3.4: Powers of Managers/Members

Managers/Members shall have the power to:

(a) Manage the Company's business and affairs;

(b) Enter into contracts on behalf of the Company;

(c) Hire employees and independent contractors;

(d) Open bank accounts and sign checks;

(e) Borrow money and grant liens (subject to limitations);

(f) Sell, lease, or otherwise dispose of Company assets (subject to limitations);

(g) Make distributions to Members;

(h) Take any other action necessary or appropriate to conduct the Company's business.

### Section 3.5: Limitations on Authority

Notwithstanding Section 3.4, the following actions require the consent of Members holding [PERCENTAGE]% of membership interests:

(a) Amending this Agreement;

(b) Admitting new Members;

(c) Dissolving the Company;

(d) Selling all or substantially all of the Company's assets;

(e) Merging or consolidating the Company;

(f) Incurring debt in excess of $[AMOUNT];

(g) Making capital expenditures in excess of $[AMOUNT];

(h) [OTHER SPECIFIED ACTIONS].

---

## ARTICLE IV: DISTRIBUTIONS

### Section 4.1: Distribution of Profits

Profits shall be distributed to Members in proportion to their membership interests, unless otherwise agreed.

### Section 4.2: Allocation of Losses

Losses shall be allocated to Members in proportion to their membership interests, subject to tax law limitations.

### Section 4.3: Distribution Timing

Distributions may be made:

(a) At such times as determined by Managers/Members;

(b) Upon liquidation of the Company;

(c) As required by law;

(d) [SPECIFY REGULAR DISTRIBUTION SCHEDULE, IF ANY].

### Section 4.4: Tax Distributions

To the extent the Company has taxable income allocated to Members, the Company shall make distributions sufficient to cover Members' tax liabilities on such income, subject to available cash.

### Section 4.5: Withholding

The Company may withhold amounts from distributions as required by law or as otherwise agreed.

---

## ARTICLE V: BOOKS AND RECORDS

### Section 5.1: Books and Records

The Company shall maintain:

(a) Books of account showing all Company transactions;

(b) Membership ledger showing all Members and their interests;

(c) Minutes of meetings (if any);

(d) Copies of all contracts and agreements;

(e) Tax returns and financial statements;

(f) Other records required by law or this Agreement.

### Section 5.2: Accounting Method

The Company shall use the [CASH/ACCRUAL] method of accounting for tax purposes, unless otherwise required by law.

### Section 5.3: Fiscal Year

The Company's fiscal year shall end on [DATE] of each year, unless changed with IRS consent.

### Section 5.4: Member Access

Members shall have the right to inspect Company books and records at reasonable times and for reasonable purposes, upon reasonable notice.

### Section 5.5: Financial Statements

The Company shall provide Members with:

(a) Annual financial statements within [NUMBER] days of fiscal year end;

(b) Tax returns within [NUMBER] days of filing;

(c) Other reports as requested by Members.

---

## ARTICLE VI: MEETINGS

### Section 6.1: Annual Meeting

An annual meeting of Members shall be held each year on [DATE] or such other date as determined by Managers/Members, for the purpose of:

(a) Reviewing Company performance;

(b) Approving financial statements;

(c) Electing Managers (if manager-managed);

(d) Transacting other business.

### Section 6.2: Special Meetings

Special meetings may be called by:

(a) Managers/Members;

(b) Members holding [PERCENTAGE]% of membership interests.

### Section 6.3: Notice

Notice of meetings shall be given at least [NUMBER] days in advance, unless waived by all Members. Notice may be given:

(a) In writing (mail, email, etc.);

(b) Orally (if confirmed in writing);

(c) As otherwise agreed by all Members.

### Section 6.4: Quorum

A quorum for meetings shall be Members holding a majority of membership interests, unless otherwise provided in this Agreement.

### Section 6.5: Action Without Meeting

Any action that may be taken at a meeting may be taken without a meeting if all Members consent in writing (including email).

### Section 6.6: Voting

Each Member shall have voting rights in proportion to his or her membership interest, unless otherwise provided in this Agreement.

---

## ARTICLE VII: TAX MATTERS

### Section 7.1: Tax Classification

The Company shall be classified as a [PARTNERSHIP/DISREGARDED ENTITY] for federal tax purposes, unless an election is made to be treated as a corporation.

### Section 7.2: Tax Elections

The Company may make any tax elections available, including:

(a) S-Corporation election (if eligible);

(b) C-Corporation election;

(c) Other elections as determined by Members.

### Section 7.3: Tax Matters Partner/Member

[IF PARTNERSHIP]: The Tax Matters Partner shall be [MEMBER NAME], who shall represent the Company in tax matters.

### Section 7.4: Tax Returns

The Company shall file all required tax returns and provide copies to Members.

---

## ARTICLE VIII: DISSOLUTION

### Section 8.1: Events of Dissolution

The Company shall dissolve upon:

(a) Unanimous consent of all Members;

(b) Entry of a decree of judicial dissolution;

(c) Any other event requiring dissolution under Wyoming law;

(d) [SPECIFY OTHER DISSOLUTION EVENTS, IF ANY].

### Section 8.2: Winding Up

Upon dissolution, the Company's affairs shall be wound up by:

(a) Liquidating Company assets;

(b) Paying Company debts and obligations;

(c) Distributing remaining assets to Members in accordance with their membership interests;

(d) Filing articles of dissolution with Wyoming Secretary of State.

### Section 8.3: Distribution Upon Dissolution

Upon dissolution, assets shall be distributed:

(a) First, to creditors (in order of priority);

(b) Second, to Members for return of capital contributions (to the extent not previously returned);

(c) Third, to Members in proportion to their membership interests.

---

## ARTICLE IX: GENERAL PROVISIONS

### Section 9.1: Governing Law

This Agreement shall be governed by Wyoming law, without regard to conflict of laws principles.

### Section 9.2: Amendments

This Agreement may be amended only with the written consent of Members holding [PERCENTAGE]% of membership interests (or as otherwise specified for particular provisions).

### Section 9.3: Severability

If any provision of this Agreement is held to be invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect.

### Section 9.4: Entire Agreement

This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the Members regarding the Company and supersedes all prior agreements and understandings.

### Section 9.5: Binding Effect

This Agreement shall be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Members and their respective heirs, successors, and assigns.

### Section 9.6: Counterparts

This Agreement may be executed in multiple counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original.

### Section 9.7: Notices

All notices required under this Agreement shall be in writing and delivered to Members at their addresses set forth in Schedule A (or as updated in writing).

---

## SIGNATURES

**Members**:

_____________________________  
[MEMBER 1 NAME]  
Date: _______________

_____________________________  
[MEMBER 2 NAME]  
Date: _______________

[ADDITIONAL MEMBERS AS NEEDED]

---

## SCHEDULE A: MEMBER INFORMATION

| Member Name | Address | Phone | Email | Membership Interest |
|-------------|---------|-------|-------|-------------------|
| [MEMBER 1] | [ADDRESS] | [PHONE] | [EMAIL] | [PERCENTAGE]% |
| [MEMBER 2] | [ADDRESS] | [PHONE] | [EMAIL] | [PERCENTAGE]% |
```

# Wyoming LLC Formation Checklist

## Purpose
This checklist ensures complete and proper formation of Wyoming LLCs for the Legacy Codex.

## Pre-Formation

- [ ] Choose LLC name
- [ ] Check name availability (Wyoming Secretary of State)
- [ ] Reserve name if needed (optional)
- [ ] Select registered agent
- [ ] Determine management structure (Member-Managed or Manager-Managed)
- [ ] Determine initial members and ownership percentages
- [ ] Plan capital contributions

## Formation Documents

- [ ] Prepare Articles of Organization
  - [ ] LLC name
  - [ ] Registered agent name and address
  - [ ] Principal office address
  - [ ] Management structure
  - [ ] Organizer information
  - [ ] Duration (perpetual or specific term)
- [ ] Review Articles for accuracy
- [ ] Sign Articles

## Filing

- [ ] File Articles of Organization with Wyoming Secretary of State
  - [ ] Online filing (recommended) OR
  - [ ] Mail filing OR
  - [ ] In-person filing
- [ ] Pay filing fee ($60)
- [ ] Receive confirmation
- [ ] Download filed documents

## Post-Formation

- [ ] Obtain EIN (Form SS-4)
  - [ ] Apply online (recommended)
  - [ ] Receive EIN immediately
- [ ] Create Operating Agreement
  - [ ] Include all required provisions
  - [ ] Customize for entity needs
  - [ ] Execute Operating Agreement
- [ ] Open business bank account
  - [ ] EIN required
  - [ ] Articles of Organization
  - [ ] Operating Agreement
  - [ ] Member resolutions (if needed)
- [ ] File Initial Report (if required)
- [ ] Obtain business licenses (if needed)
- [ ] Register for taxes (if required)
- [ ] Set up accounting system

## Series LLC (If Applicable)

- [ ] Include Series LLC provisions in Articles
- [ ] Include Series LLC provisions in Operating Agreement
- [ ] Create Series structure
- [ ] Designate assets to each Series
- [ ] Maintain separate books and records
- [ ] Maintain separate bank accounts

## Compliance Setup

- [ ] Set up compliance calendar
- [ ] Schedule annual report filing
- [ ] Set up registered agent relationship
- [ ] Establish record-keeping system
- [ ] Set up tax compliance system

## Documentation

- [ ] Organize formation documents
- [ ] File documents securely
- [ ] Create entity file
- [ ] Maintain complete records
- [ ] Update entity records as needed

## Notes

- Formation typically takes 1-3 business days for online filing
- EIN can be obtained immediately online
- Operating Agreement should be created within 90 days of formation
- All documents should be retained permanently

# Client Onboarding Email Sequence Template

## Purpose

This template provides a complete email sequence for onboarding new clients. The sequence guides clients through the onboarding process, sets expectations, and ensures a smooth transition to active service delivery.

## Instructions

1. **Customize**: Replace all [PLACEHOLDERS] with actual information
2. **Schedule**: Set up automated sequence or send manually
3. **Personalize**: Add specific details about client's service
4. **Time**: Send emails at appropriate intervals (see timing below)
5. **Track**: Monitor opens, clicks, and responses
6. **Adjust**: Modify sequence based on client feedback

## Email Sequence

### Email 1: Welcome Email (Day 0 - Immediately after contract)

**Subject**: Welcome to [COMPANY NAME] - Let's Get Started!

**Timing**: Send within 24 hours of contract execution

**Template**: See `email-client-welcome.md`

```markdown
[YOUR TITLE]
```

---

## Sequence Summary

| Email | Timing | Purpose | Key Action |
|-------|--------|---------|------------|
| Welcome | Day 0 | Welcome and introduction | Set expectations |
| Preparation | Day 1 | Prepare for kickoff | Gather information |
| Post-Kickoff | Day 2 | Follow up on call | Confirm next steps |
| Account Ready | Day 3-5 | Account setup complete | Access portal |
| First Delivery | Day 7-14 | First service delivered | Review deliverables |
| Check-In | Day 14-21 | Gather feedback | Collect feedback |
| Complete | Day 30 | Onboarding complete | Transition to ongoing |

## Best Practices

- **Personalization**: Customize each email with client-specific information
- **Timing**: Send emails at appropriate intervals (not too frequent, not too sparse)
- **Value**: Each email should provide value, not just check boxes
- **Responsiveness**: Respond promptly to client replies
- **Tracking**: Monitor email opens, clicks, and responses
- **Adjustment**: Modify sequence based on client feedback and results

## Variations

### Short Sequence (Simple Services)
- Welcome Email
- Account Ready Email
- First Delivery Email

### Extended Sequence (Complex Services)
- Add additional check-in emails
- Add training emails
- Add resource emails

# Independent Contractor Agreement Template

## Purpose

This agreement is for hiring freelancers, consultants, or virtual assistants (VAs). It clearly establishes that the worker is *not* an employee, which is critical for tax and liability purposes.

## Instructions

1.  **Scope**: Define the specific services in Exhibit A.
2.  **Status**: Reinforce independent status (no taxes withheld, no benefits).
3.  **IP**: Ensure "Work for Hire" language is present so you own the output.

## Template

```markdown
# INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR AGREEMENT

**Date**: [DATE]

**Company**: [COMPANY NAME]
**Contractor**: [CONTRACTOR NAME]

## 1. SERVICES

Contractor agrees to perform the services described in **Exhibit A** (the "Services"). Contractor shall determine the method, details, and means of performing the Services.

## 2. COMPENSATION

Company shall pay Contractor as follows:
-   **Rate**: $[AMOUNT] per [HOUR/PROJECT]
-   **Payment Terms**: Invoices payable within [NUMBER] days.

## 3. INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR RELATIONSHIP

Contractor is an independent contractor, not an employee.
-   Contractor is responsible for all federal, state, and local taxes.
-   Contractor is not eligible for Company benefits (health insurance, PTO, etc.).
-   Company will not withhold taxes from payments.

## 4. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY (WORK FOR HIRE)

4.1 **Ownership**. All work product created by Contractor for Company ("Work Product") shall be considered a "work made for hire" and shall be the sole property of Company.
4.2 **Assignment**. If any Work Product does not qualify as a work made for hire, Contractor hereby assigns all right, title, and interest in such Work Product to Company.

## 5. CONFIDENTIALITY

Contractor agrees to keep all Company information confidential and not to disclose it to third parties or use it for any purpose other than performing the Services.

## 6. TERM AND TERMINATION

6.1 **Term**. This Agreement commences on [START DATE] and continues until [END DATE] or completion of Services.
6.2 **Termination**. Either party may terminate this Agreement with [NUMBER] days' written notice.

## 7. INDEMNIFICATION

Contractor agrees to indemnify Company against any claims arising out of Contractor's negligence, misconduct, or breach of this Agreement.

## 8. GOVERNING LAW

This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of [STATE].

---

**SIGNATURES**:

**Company**:
__________________________
[NAME], [TITLE]

**Contractor**:
__________________________
[NAME]

---

## EXHIBIT A: SCOPE OF SERVICES

[Detailed description of tasks, deliverables, and deadlines]
```

---

**Last Updated**: [DATE]

# Single-Member Operating Agreement Template (Wyoming LLC)

## 1. Formation
This Operating Agreement is entered into as of **[Date]** by **[Member Name]** (the "Member"), as the sole member of **[LLC Name]** (the "Company").

## 2. Purpose
The Company is formed for the purpose of engaging in any lawful act or activity for which limited liability companies may be formed under the Wyoming Limited Liability Company Act.

## 3. Management
The Company shall be **Manager-Managed**.
*   **Manager**: [Manager Name] (e.g., PNR Holdings LLC or Individual)
*   The Manager has full authority to bind the Company, sign contracts, and manage daily operations.

## 4. Capital Contributions
The Member has contributed the following cash/assets:
*   **Initial Contribution**: $[Amount]

## 5. Distributions
Distributions of Net Cash Flow shall be made to the Member at such times and in such amounts as the Manager determines.

## 6. Liability of Member
The Member shall not be liable for the debts, obligations, or liabilities of the Company, except as provided by law.

## 7. Charging Order Protection
The parties agree that the exclusive remedy of a judgment creditor of the Member shall be a Charging Order against the Member's transferable interest. The creditor shall have no right to seize assets, vote, or participate in management.

## 8. Dissolution
The Company shall dissolve upon the written consent of the Member or the entry of a decree of judicial dissolution.

# Template Creation Guide

## Overview

This guide provides systematic instructions for creating the remaining 1,000+ templates for the Legacy Codex. Use this guide to ensure consistency, completeness, and quality across all templates.

## Template Creation Process

### Step 1: Identify Template Need

1. Review the Template Index (`TEMPLATE_INDEX.md`)
2. Identify missing templates
3. Prioritize by:
   - Frequency of use
   - Criticality to operations
   - Dependencies (templates needed by other templates)
   - Chapter references in Empire Book

### Step 2: Research and Gather Information

1. Review Empire Book Outline for requirements
2. Review existing similar templates for consistency
3. Research industry standards and best practices
4. Review source materials (if available)
5. Consult subject matter experts (if needed)

### Step 3: Create Template Structure

Every template must include:

```markdown
# [Template Name]

## Purpose
[Clear statement of what the template is for and when to use it]

## Instructions
[Step-by-step instructions for using the template]

## Template
[The actual fillable template with [FIELD NAME] placeholders]

## Example
[Example filled version - optional but recommended]

## Notes
[Additional considerations, warnings, or best practices]

---
**Version**: X.X
**Last Updated**: [DATE]
**Next Review**: [DATE]
```

### Step 4: Define Fields

For each `[FIELD NAME]` placeholder:

1. **Name Clearly**: Use descriptive, unambiguous names
2. **Provide Context**: Include field descriptions where helpful
3. **Specify Format**: Indicate expected format (date, currency, text, etc.)
4. **Mark Required**: Clearly mark required vs. optional fields
5. **Provide Examples**: Include example values where helpful

### Step 5: Add Instructions

Instructions should be:

- **Clear**: Easy to understand
- **Sequential**: Step-by-step process
- **Complete**: Cover all necessary steps
- **Actionable**: Specific actions, not vague guidance
- **Numbered**: Use numbered lists for sequential steps

### Step 6: Include Examples

Where helpful, include:

- **Filled Example**: Show template with sample data
- **Multiple Scenarios**: Different use cases if applicable
- **Common Mistakes**: What to avoid
- **Best Practices**: Tips for effective use

### Step 7: Quality Review

Before finalizing:

- [ ] All placeholders are clearly defined
- [ ] Instructions are complete and clear
- [ ] Template follows standard format
- [ ] No placeholders remain undefined
- [ ] Example is accurate (if included)
- [ ] Notes are helpful and relevant
- [ ] Version information is included
- [ ] File is saved in correct directory

## Template Categories and Standards

### Legal Templates

**Standards**:
- Must include legal disclaimer
- Must reference need for attorney review
- Must comply with applicable laws
- Must include execution requirements
- Must include signature blocks

**Common Sections**:
- Recitals
- Definitions
- Main provisions
- General provisions
- Signatures
- Schedules/Exhibits

### Financial Templates

**Standards**:
- Must include accounting method (cash/accrual)
- Must include period/date fields
- Must include calculation formulas
- Must include variance analysis (where applicable)
- Must reference accounting standards

**Common Sections**:
- Header information
- Revenue/Income
- Expenses/Costs
- Calculations
- Summary/Totals
- Notes/Comments

### Operational Templates

**Standards**:
- Must include purpose and scope
- Must include responsibilities
- Must include step-by-step process
- Must include quality standards
- Must include escalation procedures

**Common Sections**:
- Purpose
- Scope
- Responsibilities
- Process Steps
- Quality Standards
- Tools/Resources
- Escalation

### Marketing Templates

**Standards**:
- Must include purpose and use case
- Must include customization instructions
- Must include best practices
- Must include follow-up guidance
- Must be brand-consistent

**Common Sections**:
- Purpose
- Instructions
- Template
- Example
- Variations
- Best Practices
- Follow-Up

## Field Naming Conventions

### Standard Field Formats

- **Dates**: `[DATE]` or `[MONTH], [YEAR]` or `[EFFECTIVE DATE]`
- **Names**: `[NAME]` or `[FIRST NAME]` `[LAST NAME]` or `[CLIENT NAME]`
- **Amounts**: `$[AMOUNT]` or `[AMOUNT]` (specify currency if not USD)
- **Percentages**: `[PERCENTAGE]%` or `[PERCENTAGE]`
- **Addresses**: `[ADDRESS]` or break down: `[STREET]`, `[CITY]`, `[STATE]`, `[ZIP]`
- **Phone**: `[PHONE]` or `[PHONE NUMBER]`
- **Email**: `[EMAIL]` or `[EMAIL ADDRESS]`
- **Entity Names**: `[ENTITY NAME]` or `[COMPANY NAME]` or `[LLC NAME]`
- **EIN/SSN**: `[EIN]` or `[SSN]` (be careful with SSN - avoid if possible)

### Context-Specific Fields

- **Legal**: `[SETTLOR NAME]`, `[TRUSTEE NAME]`, `[BENEFICIARY NAME]`
- **Financial**: `[REVENUE AMOUNT]`, `[EXPENSE AMOUNT]`, `[NET INCOME]`
- **Operational**: `[PROCESS NAME]`, `[RESPONSIBLE PARTY]`, `[DUE DATE]`
- **Marketing**: `[CLIENT NAME]`, `[SERVICE NAME]`, `[CAMPAIGN NAME]`

## Directory Structure

Templates must be saved in the correct directory:

```
templates/
├── legal/
│   ├── trusts/
│   ├── entities/
│   ├── real-estate/
│   └── contracts/
├── financial/
│   ├── statements/
│   ├── budgets/
│   ├── forecasts/
│   └── tax/
├── operational/
│   ├── sops/
│   ├── workflows/
│   └── processes/
└── marketing/
    ├── emails/
    ├── scripts/
    └── proposals/
```

## File Naming Conventions

- **Format**: `[template-name].md`
- **Use lowercase**: All lowercase letters
- **Use hyphens**: Separate words with hyphens (not underscores or spaces)
- **Be descriptive**: Name should clearly indicate template purpose
- **Examples**:
  - `Legacy-trust-template.md` ✓
  - `profit-loss-monthly.md` ✓
  - `sop-client-onboarding.md` ✓
  - `email-client-welcome.md` ✓

## Version Control

Every template must include:

```markdown
---
**Version**: X.X
**Last Updated**: [DATE]
**Next Review**: [DATE]
```

- **Version**: Start at 1.0, increment for major changes
- **Last Updated**: Date template was last modified
- **Next Review**: Date for next scheduled review (typically 1 year)

## Quality Checklist

Before marking a template complete:

- [ ] Template follows standard format
- [ ] Purpose is clearly stated
- [ ] Instructions are complete
- [ ] All fields are clearly defined
- [ ] No undefined placeholders remain
- [ ] Example is included (where helpful)
- [ ] Notes provide helpful guidance
- [ ] Version information included
- [ ] File saved in correct directory
- [ ] File name follows conventions
- [ ] Template added to index
- [ ] Legal disclaimer included (for legal templates)
- [ ] Reviewed for accuracy and completeness

## Batch Creation Strategy

To efficiently create 1,000+ templates:

1. **Create by Category**: Complete one category before moving to next
2. **Start with Most Critical**: Prioritize frequently-used templates
3. **Use Templates**: Create templates from existing similar templates
4. **Batch Similar**: Group similar templates together
5. **Review in Batches**: Review multiple templates at once
6. **Update Index**: Update index as templates are created

## Template Dependencies

Some templates depend on others:

- **Legal Templates**: May reference other legal templates
- **Financial Templates**: May build on base statement templates
- **Operational Templates**: May reference checklist templates
- **Marketing Templates**: May reference other marketing templates

Create base templates first, then dependent templates.

## Common Template Patterns

### Agreement Templates

```markdown
# [AGREEMENT NAME]

## PARTIES
[Party 1]
[Party 2]

## RECITALS
WHEREAS...

## ARTICLE I: [TOPIC]
### Section 1.1: [Subsection]
...

## SIGNATURES
[Signature blocks]
```

### Form Templates

```markdown
# [FORM NAME]

**Date**: [DATE]
**Entity**: [ENTITY NAME]

## [SECTION 1]
[Fields and checkboxes]

## [SECTION 2]
[Fields and checkboxes]

**Signature**: _______________
**Date**: _______________
```

### Checklist Templates

```markdown
# [CHECKLIST NAME]

## [CATEGORY 1]
- [ ] Item 1
- [ ] Item 2

## [CATEGORY 2]
- [ ] Item 1
- [ ] Item 2
```

### SOP Templates

```markdown
# SOP: [PROCESS NAME]

## Purpose
## Scope
## Responsibilities
## Process Steps
### Step 1: [Description]
- [ ] Action item
## Quality Standards
## Tools and Resources
```

## Updating the Index

After creating templates:

1. Open `TEMPLATE_INDEX.md`
2. Find appropriate section
3. Add template entry:
   - File name
   - Brief description
   - Link (if applicable)
4. Update statistics
5. Save index

## Maintenance Schedule

- **Monthly**: Review templates created that month
- **Quarterly**: Review template usage and update as needed
- **Annually**: Comprehensive review of all templates
- **As Needed**: Update templates when laws/regulations change

## Getting Help

If stuck on a template:

1. Review similar existing templates
2. Check Empire Book Outline for requirements
3. Research industry standards
4. Consult subject matter experts
5. Review source materials
